doc_title: A Pseudonymisation Protocol with Implicit and Explicit Consent Routes for Health Records in Federated Ledgers
doc_abstract: © 2013 IEEE.Healthcare data for primary use (diagnosis) may be encrypted for confidentiality purposes; however, secondary uses such as feeding machine learning algorithms requires open access. Full anonymity has no traceable identifiers to report diagnosis results. Moreover, implicit and explicit consent routes are of practical importance under recent data protection regulations (GDPR), translating directly into break-the-glass requirements. Pseudonymisation is an acceptable compromise when dealing with such orthogonal requirements and is an advisable measure to protect data. Our work presents a pseudonymisation protocol that is compliant with implicit and explicit consent routes. The protocol is constructed on a (t,n)-threshold secret sharing scheme and public key cryptography. The pseudonym is safely derived from a fragment of public information without requiring any data-subject's secret. The method is proven secure under reasonable cryptographic assumptions and scalable from the experimental results.

With billions of devices connected via the Internet, opportunities for smart applications increase tremendously. Unfortunately that is also the case for the risks. This means that security and privacy of the Internet of Things are aspects that need to be addressed timely and thoroughly. This briefing paper points out that when designing and implementing infrastructures and applications a number of questions need to be answered in order to take well-founded decisions. Addressing these questions is the responsibility of a variety of stakeholders. The roles and responsibilities of the various groups of players are introduced in this paper as Key points to take away. 1 What is the Internet of Things? The Internet of Things, or IoT, could be labelled as “buzzword”, a fashionable term that has become very popular. IoT is nonetheless an important and dynamically evolving aspect of the ICT field. But what does it mean? As already mentioned in the IFIP Position Paper “IoT: Do we have a choice?” (IoT March 2019) there are many definitions of the IoT. Moreover, definitions evolve over time as mentioned also in the Wikipedia page on the IoT A combination of some definitions gives a good idea of what the IoT is: “The Internet of Things (IoT) is the inter-networking of physical devices (also referred to as “thing”, “object”, “connected devices” or “smart devices”) such as vehicles, buildings, and other items such as home appliances embedded with electronics, software, sensors, actuators, and network connectivity, which enable these devices to collect and exchange data and interact with others over the Internet, possibly for remote monitoring and control.” As is often the case with buzzwords, variations are used to specify subsets or to give a different perspective. This also applies to the Internet of Things, with terms such as the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), the Internet of Everything (IoE), and – as a more discipline-specific example – the Internet of Medical Things (or indeed Internet of Health Things). As long as the reader has a general sense of what the IoT is, the exact definition in principle is not the most important element. However, it is important to realize that there are differences between a consumer-oriented environment and an industry-oriented environment. Examples of the consumer-oriented environment are smart home applications for energy management and for assisting elderly people and people with disabilities. Industry-oriented environments include cyber-physical systems in for instance smart energy grids and process control in supply chain networks. 2 Why is security and privacy important? The growth in the number of connected devices is almost beyond imagination. Many consultancy and market research companies present statistics and predictions (10 Charts That Will Challenge Your Perspective Of IoT's Growth June 2018; Roundup Of Internet Of Things December 2018). For example: IoT adoption gaining momentum 2016 2017 2018 2030 IoT units installed base - total (m) 6,382 8,381 11,197 125,000 Consumer devices (m) 3,963 5,244 7,036 75,000 Consumer devices as a% of total devices 62% 63% 63% 60% Connected devices per person 5 5 5 5 World population (m) 7,400 7,600 7,700 8,500 IoT adoption rate 11% 14% 18% 176% Source: DBS Bank based on estimates by Gartner, United Nations, World Bank In: Internet of Things: The Pillar of Artificial Intelligence – Sector Briefing Number 63 – DBS Asian Insights – DBS Group Research – June 2018 (Internet of Things June 2018). Given these figures it is almost inevitable that most, if not all of us, will be confronted with Internet connected devices in our home or work environment. Devices collecting data about our behavior and wishes, about our systems’ states and changes and about our physical and perhaps even mental condition. Devices acting upon these data by automatically replenishing stock, adjusting positions, advising us to move into a certain direction, prescribing medicine, etcetera. The risk of faulty decisions, either by mistake or on purpose, is increasing. This requires extra attention for security and privacy issues in the IoT. 3 What are the security and privacy concerns with respect to IoT? The increasing number of connected devices also increases the security and privacy threats. Cases of malware infected devices in the consumer environment being used for DDoS attacks on industrial applications (think for instance on Internet banking systems) are already a reality. A well-known case is the Mirai malware. 1 1 [accessed 16-02-2020] The growing number of devices collecting data about individuals also makes it more and more difficult to stay in control of your personal data. That increases the risk of privacy breaches. While most security threats do apply to the Internet of Things, they are on the one hand not specific for the IoT, on the other hand the risks may be bigger due to the numbers. Take for instance unauthorised access to devices enabling an unauthorised person to interfere with or collect data. If we talk about billions of connected devices, it is obvious that the risk of this happening is substantial. In addition, the consequences of threats that materialized are much bigger. Confidentiality, integrity and availability remain the key objectives, but there are specific features when addressing security and privacy issues for IoT infrastructure and applications. A whole lot of questions have to be answered in order to take well-founded decisions: • who collects data; • where are they stored; • who has access to the data; • are data anonymized; • who is responsible for the security; • who decides what an acceptable risk level is; • who owns the data; • how much control do users have on their own data • what are the liability arrangements; • what can be legally enforced in terms of collecting data; • who is responsible for decisions based on incorrect data; • can you opt in or opt out; • who takes care of communications security; • etcetera. Addressing these questions is a responsibility of the players involved: ICT professionals, users (both consumers and companies), ICT industry, authorities / regulators. All players can and must contribute to developing, implementing and using a safe and secure IoT infrastructure and applications. What roles and responsibilities the various groups of players have is briefly introduced in the next chapter: Key points to take away. 4 Key points to take away 4.1 ICT professionals ICT professionals should have sufficient professional and ethical competences to make the right choices when designing, developing, implementing, operating or managing software / hardware as part of an Internet of Things that is able to offer choices to its users. Having sufficient professional and ethical competences is a general requirement for ICT professionals. However, in an IoT environment this is especially important because users may not be aware of the fact that choices are, could or should be possible. Users also may not be in a position to demand choices or to influence the usage of collected data. Therefore, the professionals should see to it that such choices are embedded and offered. Users should be informed about the benefits and risks of Internet of Things applications they use. If the owner or developer of such applications does not (sufficiently) inform the users, ICT professionals have a choice, maybe even a duty, to do this (for instance via research papers and publications). In order to be able to do this, there should be no legal liability when publishing such results. 4.2 Users Users at least must have a choice to switch off the connection or not use the smart part of smart devices. In other words, users should have an opt in or opt out choice. They should be able to control and personalize the behavior of smart objects and associated applications. There may be applications or circumstances where it is not possible or desirable to give users an opt in or opt out choice, for instance in cases where national security is at stake. When this is the case, it should be clearly explained to users. Users should inform themselves about the various aspects (benefits / risks) of the devices that are connected in the IoT they are using. A condition to help users is the availability of “a set of the right questions”. 4.3 ICT industry ICT industry providing IoT applications and systems should inform users about the benefits and potential risks. It has to be clear for users for which purposes data are collected. A mechanism needs to be in place to assure the security and protection of such collected data and providers should inform users about these mechanisms. It should also be made clear what the consequences of either choice (opt in or opt out) are. ICT industry should not develop IoT applications that provide data that can be used without the owners of the data knowing about the use or consenting to it. The ICT industry providing IoT applications and devices must ensure that every element in the IoT architecture is secure. This includes hardware/devices, communications as well as applications. All these elements have to work together to secure end-to-end security, because one weakness can lead to a security breach of a complete system. Many methods of securing all these areas in the IoT architecture exist, and it is important for the reader to understand that IoT architecture might have different and unique security needs compared with traditional systems. The ability to create and maintain a secure end-to-end infrastructure will require well-defined cybersecurity policies and active collaboration between standard bodies, policymakers, regulators, and enterprises. 4.4 Authorities / regulators Policymakers and regulators should take into account the interests of users when regulating the use of (personal) data (including data that can be linked to a person in an indirect way e.g. via home, car, etc.). It is important that policies and regulations provide the conditions for the choices that users and providers can or should be able to make. Professionals and users working in standard setting bodies have to provide guidance for choosing and using standards. When it comes to IoT standards, many standards, frameworks and guidelines have been published. One can argue that with too many standards, frameworks and controls to choose from, there is a likelihood of implementing either the wrong standard or none at all. That would not help managing the risks. doc_title: Complementing vehicular connectivity coverage through cellular networks
doc_abstract: © 2020 IEEE.Vehicular Ad hoc Networks (VANETs) support the development of safety and infotainment applications, allowing vehicles to communicate between each other and with the infrastructure, assuring their connection and of its occupants to the Internet These VANETs may rely on different technologies for their deployment, such as IEEE 802.11p/vVAVE, C-V2X or Wi-Fi; however, complete coverage and full connectivity may not be assured. This work integrates, in a seamless approach, an additional communication interface via cellular networks into an existing VANET with mobility and multihoming support in order to increase its connection availability. The proposed solution makes use of commercial cellular networks without the need of any contribution by network providers, and maintaining transparency to the end-user. The validation and evaluation of the proposed solution was performed with a real network in real-world scenarios. The results showed that the proposed approach is able to maintain and increase the VANET connectivity.

doc_title: RAIAP: renewable authentication on isolated anonymous profiles: A GDPR compliant self-sovereign architecture for distributed systems
doc_abstract: © 2020, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.Implementing pseudonymity, key-management, non-repudiation and data minimisation features in isolated procedures is trivial. However, integrating all of them in one consistent architecture has several challenges to tackle. This work proposes data structures to represent Self-Sovereign Identities and to handle those features in a consolidated architecture. Key-management is constructed using secret sharing principles, capable of recovering from a lost or compromised key to a new one without losing track of the original account. Pseudonymity and data minimisation is established using anonymous profiles, showing different views of the same identity. Non-repudiation is contemplated in the profile disclosure process. Profiles are protected against tampering with the use of digital signatures and blockchain cryptographic constructions. All profiles and registries are controlled with a single asymmetric key pair that can be provided by a smart card. Flexible structures are defined that can be used to register claims, attestations, authorisation grants, user consents, or any other activities. All definitions take into consideration the rules of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

doc_title: EAP-SH: An EAP Authentication Protocol to Integrate Captive Portals in the 802.1X Security Architecture
doc_abstract: © 2020, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.In a scenario where hotspot wireless networks are increasingly being used, and given the amount of sensitive information exchanged on Internet interactions, there is the need to implement security mechanisms that guarantee data confidentiality and integrity in such networks, as well as the authenticity of the hotspot providers. However, many hotspots today use Captive Portals, which rely on authentication through Web pages (thus, an application-level authentication approach) instead of a link-layer approach. The consequence of this is that there is no security in the wireless link to the hotspot (it has to be provided at upper protocol layers), and is cumbersome to manage wireless access profiles (we need special applications or browsers’ add-ons to do that). This work exposes the weaknesses of the Captive Portals’ paradigm, which does not follow a unique nor standard approach, and describes a solution that intends to suppress them, based on the 802.1X architecture. It relies on EAP-SH (extended authentication protocol for secure hotspots), a new EAP-compliant protocol that is able to integrate a Web-based registration or authentication with a Captive Portal within the 802.1X authentication framework. This work describes its design, implementation and prototype evaluation.

doc_title: An efficient and secure alert system for vanets to improve crosswalks’ security in smart cities

Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.A key characteristic of Smart Cities is the ability to reduce conflicts between different agents coexisting in a dynamic system, such as the interaction between vehicles and pedestrians. This paper presents a system to augment the awareness of vehicle drivers regarding the presence of pedestrians in nearby crosswalks. The proposed system interconnects Road Side Units (RSUs), which are informed about the state of the crosswalks, and vehicles, in order to spread to vehicles, the information about the presence of pedestrians in crosswalks. To prevent false information spreading, RSUs sign the alert messages they broadcast and all vehicles can validate the signatures. This poses strong security requirements, such as non-repudiation of alert messages, as well as strong real-time requirements, such as minimum message validation delays among vehicles approaching a crosswalk of interest. To manage the signed alert messages, we are proposing Nimble Asymmetric Cryptography (NAC), which authenticates implicit broadcast messages. NAC minimizes the usage of asymmetric ciphers, which are fundamental to assure non-repudiation but increase performance penalties and uses hash chaining for source authentication of implicit messages.

doc_title: A Parser to Support the Definition of Access Control Policies and Rules Using Natural Languages
doc_abstract: © 2019, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.As a consequence of the epidemiological transition towards non-communicable diseases, integrated care approaches are required, not solely focused on medical purposes, but also on a range of essential activities for the maintenance of the individuals’ quality of life. In order to allow the exchange of information, these integrated approaches might be supported by digital platforms, which need to provide trustful environments and to guarantee the integrity of the information exchanged. Therefore, together with mechanisms such as authentication, logging or auditing, the definition of access control policies assumes a paramount importance. This article focuses on the development of a parser as a component of a platform to support the care of community-dwelling older adults, the SOCIAL platform, to allow the definition of access control policies and rules using natural languages.

doc_title: Evolution of HTTPS usage by Portuguese municipalities
doc_abstract: © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2020.This paper presents a study on the evolution of the use of HTTPS by the official websites of all (308) Portuguese municipalities. One year ago, we found a bad situation regarding HTTPS usage: only a small percentage of websites adopted HTTPS correctly. The results were communicated to the relevant entities so actions could be taken. After one year, we performed a new assessment to check for evolution. This paper presents the results of this second assessment. We found a significantly better situation, although still with plenty of room for improvement: 31 municipal websites were classified as Good (20 more), while 42 less were classified as Bad (100 in total). We concluded that two determinants that were identified as contributing to explain the results of the first study - municipal taxes and total population - do not contribute to explain the improvements observed in this assessment. We believe that we contributed to those improvements by raising awareness to the high number of municipalities not using or badly using HTTPS.

doc_title: Timely Classification and Verification of Network Traffic Using Gaussian Mixture Models
doc_abstract: © 2013 IEEE.We present a novel approach for timely classification and verification of network traffic using Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs). We generate a separate GMM for each class of applications using component-wise expectation-maximization (CEM) to match the network traffic distribution generated by these applications. We apply our models for both traffic classification, where the goal is to identify the source application from which the traffic originates, by evaluating the maximum posterior probability, and for traffic verification, where the goal is to verify whether the application that claims to be the source of the traffic is as expected, by likelihood testing. Our models use only the first initial packets of truncated flows in order to provide more efficient and timely traffic classification and verification. This allows for triggering timely countermeasures before the end of flows. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by experiments on a public dataset collected from a real network. Our traffic classification approach outperforms other state-of-the-art approaches that are based on machine learning, and achieves up to 97.7% flow classification accuracy when using only 9 first initial packets of flows. We show that 96.6% flow classification accuracy can still be obtained when training the GMMs using only 0.5% of all flows. Our traffic verification approach achieves a minimum Half Total Error Rate (HTER) of 7.65% when using only 6 first initial packets of flows.

doc_title: QoE of video streaming in multihomed vehicular networks
doc_abstract: © 2019 Association for Computing Machinery.With the ever-increasing interest and availability of vehicular networks, it comes now of importance to study the Quality-of-Experience (QoE) provided by these networks. Either motivated by safety or commercial applications, video streaming in such highly mobile environments offers multiple challenges. In this paper we evaluate the QoE of a multihoming communication strategy, supported simultaneously by WAVE and Wi-Fi, for increasing the reliability and performance of video streams in these environments. Furthermore, we also investigate how distinct network functionalities, such as multihoming load balance, buffering, throughput and latency affect the overall QoE observed. The results obtained led to the proposal of a multihoming load balance rule for video applications based on access technologies, aiming to improve QoE. The overall results show a QoE improvement by using the proposed approach.

doc_title: Pseudonymisation with break-the-glass compatibility for health records in federated services
doc_abstract: © 2019 IEEE.Pseudonymisation is a major requirement in recent data protection regulations, and of especial importance when sharing healthcare data outside of the boundaries of the affinity domain. However, healthcare systems require important break-the-glass procedures, such as accessing records of patients in unconscious states. Our work presents a pseudonymisation protocol that is compliant with break-the-glass procedures, established on a (t, n)-threshold secret sharing scheme and public key cryptography. The pseudonym is safely derived from a fragment of public information without any private secret requirement. The protocol is proven secure and scalable under reasonable assumptions.

doc_title: Security-oriented architecture for managing IoT deployments
doc_abstract: © 2019 by the authors.Assuring security and privacy is one of the key issues affecting the Internet of Things (IoT), mostly due to its distributed nature. Therefore, for the IoT to thrive, this problem needs to be tackled and solved. This paper describes a security-oriented architecture for managing IoT deployments. Our main goal was to deal with a fine-grained control in the access to IoT data and devices, to prevent devices from being manipulated by attackers and to avoid information leaking from IoT devices to unauthorized recipients. The access control is split: the management of authentication and access control policies is centered on special components (Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting Controllers), which can be distributed or centralized, and the actual enforcement of access control decisions happens on the entities that stay in the path to the IoT devices (Gateways and Device Drivers). The authentication in the entire system uses asymmetric cryptography and pre-distributed unique identifiers derived from public keys; no Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is used. A Kerberos-like ticket-based approach is used to establish secure sessions.

doc_title: The impact of ECDSA in a VANET routing service: Insights from real data traces
doc_abstract: © 2018 Elsevier B.V.Both the WAVE IEEE 1609.2 standard in USA and the ETSI ITS security standards in Europe rely on the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) to authenticate messages exchanged among vehicles. Although being faster than other equivalent algorithms, the ECDSA computational cost nevertheless affects the message validation throughput. Even worse, the number of messages that a device has to authenticate may easily exhaust its computational limits. In this article, we evaluated the impact caused by ECDSA authentication of messages of the multi-hop routing control plane used in a real Vehicular Ad Hoc Network (VANET). Such control plane uses periodic vicinity updates to keep accurate, distributed routing paths, and ECDSA-based validation delays may force to discard many of such updates. To perform the evaluation of the impact imposed by ECDSA we considered the multiple curve parameters associated to WAVE and ETSI ITS, their implementation by different cryptographic libraries and their performance in distinct hardware. We took as reference for traffic to be authenticated with ECDSA a day-long set of messages of a VANET routing control plane. These messages were inferred from connectivity status samples from all mobile nodes of a real VANET. Emulation results with those messages show that, without high-end computing devices, ECDSA authentication would have a substantial negative impact in the routing service of the tested VANET.

Both the WAVE IEEE 1609.2 standard in USA and the ETSI ITS security standards in Europe rely on the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) to authenticate messages exchanged among vehicles. Although being faster than other equivalent algorithms, the ECDSA computational cost nevertheless affects the message validation throughput. Even worse, the number of messages that a device has to authenticate may easily exhaust its computational limits. In this article, we evaluated the impact caused by ECDSA authentication of messages of the multi-hop routing control plane used in a real Vehicular Ad Hoc Network (VANET). Such control plane uses periodic vicinity updates to keep accurate, distributed routing paths, and ECDSA-based validation delays may force to discard many of such updates. To perform the evaluation of the impact imposed by ECDSA we considered the multiple curve parameters associated to WAVE and ETSI ITS, their implementation by different cryptographic libraries and their performance in distinct hardware. We took as reference for traffic to be authenticated with ECDSA a day-long set of messages of a VANET routing control plane. These messages were inferred from connectivity status samples from all mobile nodes of a real VANET. Emulation results with those messages show that, without high-end computing devices, ECDSA authentication would have a substantial negative impact in the routing service of the tested VANET. Keywords VANET Broadcast authentication ECDSA Performance evaluation 1 Introduction Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) are networks that possess a constantly changing topology, and therefore, are very challenging for setting up the ordinary end-to-end IP routing. In particular, the control plane that manages routing paths (ordinary IP routing, georouting, etc.) has to take timely and accurate decisions to have a reasonably high delivery rate. This means that adding security to such scenario, namely source authentication of messages received by VANET nodes, has the potential to partially or totally disrupt the overall routing effectiveness of the VANET. Both WAVE IEEE 1609 [1] and ETSI ITS-G5 [2] make use of the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) to authenticate broadcast messages exchanged among devices. For the same level of security, ECDSA is faster and produces shorter signatures when compared with other alternative algorithms [3]. In spite of mitigating the impact of source authentication, the computational overhead imposed by ECDSA was already associated to delays and losses of safety information [4] and to the degradation of applications related with emergency braking signalling and crash avoidance [5,6]. In the case of a routing service, the impact of using ECDSA (according to WAVE IEEE 1609 or ETSI ITS-G5) was never addressed by the research community. Since the debut of VANETs, there has been a significant number of proposals for their traffic routing, and the topic is still very challenging in practice [7,8]. The most challenging task in a VANET routing service is to keep the information updated and propagate the changes as fast as possible. Therefore, we can easily envision that the effectiveness of secure routing service will naturally depend on the overhead associated to the applied security mechanisms, since these impose delays. In this article, we evaluate the minimum impact of the ECDSA computational overhead when used by an IP routing service in a VANET. By minimum we mean that we consider only overheads resulting from the validation of signatures in received messages from the routing control plane. We do not consider overheads imposed by protocols to distribute and validate the public keys of the vehicles, by the production of signatures by transmitters and by the authentication of IP traffic. ECDSA overheads are evaluated considering alternative elliptic curve parameters, libraries and hardware. For our evaluation we take as reference data collected from a real VANET, deployed in the city of Porto, Portugal. This VANET uses the IEEE 1609.2 standard and interconnects buses, which makes it sparse. 1 1 The data was collected from a maximum of 210 active devices at the same time in an area of 35 km2 and a maximum of 57 neighbours per device. The original contributions of this study are: • An analysis of the impact of ECDSA validations, when used by a routing service exploiting WAVE IEEE 1609 and ETSI ITS-G5, performed by recent versions of multiple cryptographic libraries, considering a current device of our reference VANET, as well as alternative hardware; • The results showing that, without high-end computing devices, the computational overhead associated to ECDSA has a relevant impact in the VANET’s routing service, in spite of the VANET’s sparsity and its resilience to message delays up to one second. 2 2 Because routing tables are updated by the second. The document is organised as follows. In Section 2 we present the related work. In Section 3 we characterise the VANET used as reference in this study. In Section 4 we measure the performance of multiple implementations of ECDSA in different CPU architectures. In Section 5 we evaluate the impact of ECDSA validations in the routing service of our reference VANET. Finally, Section 6 concludes the document and highlights future work. 2 Related work WAVE IEEE 1609 and ETSI ITS-G5 rely on ECDSA for source authentication [1,2]. Both standards assume the possibility of multi-hop connectivity and IP support, but the computational impact of ECDSA on routing in VANETs was never a topic of study. This means that the losses on number (or quality) of routes, as well as the amount of traffic to be routed and discarded due to ECDSA overheads are unknown metrics. Even so, the computational impact of ECDSA has been a justification to define alternative strategies to build secure routing protocols from scratch to VANETs [9,10], but the impact of applying ECDSA source authentication to already existing (insecure) routing strategies, that perform well in some scenarios, is also an unknown. In this work we analyse the impact of upgrading an insecure routing service, currently deployed in a city-scale VANET, into a secure one, according to WAVE IEEE 1609. The analysis focuses on the impact of ECDSA on the number and quality of routes, as well as the routing information discarded by devices. In 2005, Raya and Hubaux [11] claimed that the ability to verify a signature in 1.5 microseconds was enough to fulfil VANET’s safety requirements. This claim was based on a simple assumption of vehicles’ distribution over a highway, a broadcast of messages in periods of 300 ms, and the need to validate up to 120 messages per 300 microseconds. These conditions are not compatible with higher broadcast frequencies, such as 10 Hz as suggested by WAVE IEEE 1609 [12]. Furthermore, they are not compatible with the existence of other services or applications running in the device and consuming part of its resources [13]. To the best of our knowledge, the studies that analyse the impact of ECDSA in VANETs were explicitly associated to scenarios where low latency for safety messages are explored [4–6,14–16]. In such cases, they all reached to the same conclusion, either directly or indirectly: the negative impact of ECDSA operations requires high-end computational devices, such as recent personal computers. However, according to Li et al.[17], a large city-scale VANET made out of personal computers is not expected to be deployed in the near future, neither it is compatible with some operational conditions, such as cost and battery consumption [18,19]. In our work we consider both high-end personal computers and the devices operating in a real VANET, which are mid-range microcomputers. In our work, which deals with non-safety messages, we did not have many assumptions for message rates, nor to their maximum acceptable delay, but we had a deployed VANET that performs well for IP routing. Therefore, we used that VANET and its IP routing service to assess the minimum overall impact that ECDSA would have in such service, which is already resilient to message delays up to 1 s. Dai et al.[20] implemented and tested a WAVE-based secured vehicular communication system. They presented a set of results from tests made with real devices, but only with a limited population and not according to the mobility patterns expected to be found in a city. In the tests they used a single library implementing ECDSA, but no justification was provided for the selection criteria. They concluded that ECDSA can fulfil the requirement of message broadcast authentication within 100 ms, and that the performance of security algorithms can be improved. Comparing our work with this last one, with respect to the performance of ECDSA operations, we first tested a large set of candidate libraries, in order to find out the topmost of them in terms of computation speed, and we used them as reference. Regarding the evaluation of the impact of ECDSA operations, we used real traces collected from an operational VANET, instead of relying on real tests on a VANET. This allowed us to analyse a scenario with hundreds of devices without the logistic problems of real tests, and still, take the benefits of the mobility and propagation information implicitly provided by the sampled VANET. Furthermore, it allowed us to assess the impact of ECDSA on the exact same mobility and propagation circumstances (inferred from the samples). Bendouma and Bensaber [21] proposed a protocol for authenticating RSUs using elliptic curve cryptography. Their proposal disregards the authentication of OBUs among themselves and evaluates the protocol only for a single and fast CPU type, which is not representative of a typical VANET device (AMD Opteron 8354 @ 2.2GHz), and uses a single cryptographic library (Crypto++), which is among the slowest that we have evaluated. Therefore, their (absolute) results could not be used to extrapolate information in the study that we performed for our target VANET. Furthermore, the authors did not evaluate the impact of authentication delays in any other service. Ravi and Kulkarni [22] proposed to use ECDSA for authenticating traffic routed with AODV (Ad hoc On-demand Distance Vector). Since AODV is completely different from the routing protocol used in our target VANET (SB2RP, see Section 3), their results cannot be extrapolated. Furthermore, they used a single, Java implementation for ECDSA, whilst we looked for faster libraries (written in assembly, C or C++) and we chose the faster one for our tests. 3 Characterisation of the reference VANET Our work is based on the VANET [23] operating in the metropolitan area of the city of Porto, Portugal, which implements an (insecure) IP routing service, known as Service-Based Layer-2 Routing Protocol (SB2RP) [24]. This VANET includes 396 On Board Units (OBUs), carried by buses, and 50 Road Side Units (RSUs), mostly placed in the centre of an area with nearly 400 km2. IP routing is currently used to connect OBUs with a central infrastructure (through RSUs), in order to provide Internet connectivity to bus passengers. IP routes within the VANET are limited to a maximum of 3 hops along OBUs. Since the VANET spans the area covered by the buses, but RSUs are not homogeneously scattered in that area, we do not consider areas where OBUs cannot have multi-hop connectivity with any RSU. Therefore, we restricted our study to a 35 km2 central area where IP routes to the Internet exist (Fig. 1 ). This means that data samples collected by each OBU were discarded when the OBU was operating outside the restricted area. SB2RP is a WAVE application that implements a periodic distance-vector routing protocol to route IP traffic between the infrastructure and OBUs. Routing control plane messages (beacons) are broadcast according to the WAVE Short Message Protocol (WSMP) in periods of 100 ms. Each device stores the information received on SB2RP messages from neighbours (radio links and associated signal quality) in an auxiliary table. SB2RP messages sent by the VANET devices are built based on the most recent information present on the auxiliary table. For quickly removing stale routing paths, the auxiliary table is a short-term cache: entries older than 1.5 s are removed. IP routing tables are updated by each second with the information stored in the auxiliary table. For each possible destination, it is selected the shortest path with the best quality. The quality is given by the sum of all RSSIs (Received Signal Strength Indications) of all links belonging to a multi-hop path. For our performance tests, we used the 4th generation of hardware used by VENIAM 3 3 www.veniam.com in both OBU and RSU devices of our target VANET at the time of writing. These are equipped with an ARM Cortex-A7 CPU (i.MX 6 at 800 MHz) and running a Linux kernel to support a small set of tools. This hardware is representative of characteristics commonly found in VANET devices [17,25]. Our scenario represents a VANET where only a relatively small number of the vehicles present in the city are part of the network, which facilitates the deployment of new features. Given an operational service (IP routing), the motivation was to analyse the possibility of using the IEEE 1609.2 to add security (source authentication) to this insecure application without a serious degradation of the service. While surveying works related with the computational overhead of IEEE 1609.2 [4–6], it became evident that none of them would be useful to answer our question, since they all analysed most demanding scenarios assoto safety applications. Compared with the previous analysis targeting safety applications, there are three prominent differences: • Our VANET encompasses only public buses, being sparser (and thus, requiring fewer validations per second) than vehicular networks formed by all vehicles, either in urban or highway scenarios [4–6,8]. • Its IP routing service is used to allow buses’ passengers to have a best-effort Internet access, thus its distributed operation is more tolerant to delays and losses of neighbouring information than any safety application. While IP tables are updated by the second, based on information collected in the last 1.5s, the same cannot happen for safety applications (e.g., 1 s at 60 km/h represents 16.7 m, which can be relevant for taking timely decisions). • The vehicles’ anonymity is not a requirement, and so, pseudonyms are not needed. This allows us to assume that, after an initial period, all certificates were already verified once and each received message just needs one signature validation to be authenticated (the best case scenario). 4 Computational cost of ECDSA validations The ECDSA is used together with a set of parameters that define the elliptic curve (EC) and some auxiliary values. There are multiple specifications of parameters proposed independently by institutions and individuals [36–39]. One of the parameters is the key length, which is associated to the computational cost of ECDSA operations and to its expected security in a near future. Longer keys lead to slower operations 4 4 Considering the same underlying algorithms and implementations. and provide more security. With a key length of 224 bit or more, ECDSA has an acceptable security until 2030 [40]. Both WAVE IEEE 1609 and ETSI ITS-G5 specify the use of the EC known as NIST P256 [37], which uses a 256-bit key. In addition, WAVE IEEE 1609 also supports the EC known as Brainpool P256r1 [38]. In both standards, the ECDSA is applied to the output of a SHA-256 hash function [41]. These devices represent the 2 types of computing capabilities found in a VANET: micro and personal computers. The libraries were tested in an equivalent version of the same operating system (Debian Gnu/Linux) and compiled with GCC 7.2.0. We used the CPP programming language to build a minimal setup according to each library needs. For each of the platforms, we measured the time taken to verify a signature of the 2 ECs, NIST P256 and Brainpool P256r1. For each case we produced and validated 1000 signatures. The results show that OpenSSL provides the faster implementations of both ECs across all the devices. For NIST P256, the best case for a microcomputer, 1716 microseconds in the OBU, is about 25 times slower than the best case in a personal computer, 64 microseconds in the desktop. As expected [42], Brainpool P256r1, due to its underlying characteristics, is slower than NIST P256 in all the devices, but the difference between the 2 types of computers is reduced to a factor of 10. Considering the results for OpenSSL on the OBU and the RP3, NIST P256 is faster in the slower CPU, whilst for Brainpool P256r1 is the opposite. This occurs due to the different optimisations that can be applied to mathematical operations, and the performance of those optimisations in different CPU architectures. The use of different algorithms and implementations for the underlying mathematical operations is the main reason for the wide variations yield by different libraries [43]. The libraries with implementations in assembly language are the ones with the best performance. OpenSSL has an assembly implementation of the 2 ECs tested for all the CPU architectures in analysis, which justifies its overall winning performance. 5 Impact of ECDSA in a VANET routing service This evaluation was performed with a trace-based emulator called loop [44]. Instead of mobility and propagation models, we used 24 h (from 18: 00 to 18: 00 in February 2015) of real status traces periodically collected from a real VANET (see Section 3). These traces encompass both real mobility of the vehicles and the real connectivity between the vehicles. The status traces are formed by the information collected by each device about its GPS location and about its neighbours (identification and RSSI), saved at each 2 s. The real mobility and communication characteristics are embedded in those traces, and this allowed us to remove a huge stack of complexity, delay and possible sources of biased results. Those traces were used to recreate the transmission of WAVE messages (beacons) in our emulator according to the real scenario by using a straightforward rationale: if a device is referred in a status trace, then at least one beacon from that device was received in the last 1.5 s. Based on the lists of the neighbours per device, we simulated the transmission and reception of beacons in periods of 100ms and enforced their authentication before using them. The IP routing tables of each device are built based on the received beacons. Since the connectivity created by the routing protocol is limited up to 3 hops to an RSU, not all active devices are able to create IP routes, nor all beacons have routing information. Along the 24 h of the status traces, the number of active devices, the number of devices possible to be connected by IP routes (within the 3 hops limit of an RSU) and the correspondent neighbouring devices varied according to Fig. 2 . This figure shows the average values for intervals of 10 min, and the maximum standard deviation for the number of active OBUs and the number of OBUs within 3 hops from an RSU is σ = 9.06 . Considering the scenario described in Section 3 and the best results of Section 4, our goal was to measure the impact in the routing capability of the VANET due to the use of ECDSA according to WAVE IEEE 1609.2. We executed 64 emulations for the 24h of available traces and grouped the results in periods of 10 min. In each emulation it was used a different seed to initialise a pseudo-random number generator that provides some variability to each emulation. The variability consisted in changing the relative order in which devices broadcast beacons to each other, within a 100 ms time window. The 95% confidence level of the mean values used to calculate the percentages presented in Figs. 3 –5 is smaller than 0.1% of the correspondent mean, in all the cases. Metrics related with the validation of routing messages were updated each 100 ms, while the ones related with IP routes were updated each 1 s. We used the computational time shown in Table 2 to derive an upper bound for the number of signatures possible to validate in an OBU currently deployed in the target VANET. Since an OBU has to do more than building routing tables, we assumed that utmost 25% of its CPU could be reserved for the authentication of beacons. Considering the library with the faster validation time for the OBU in Table 2 (OpenSSL, 1.7 ms per validation) and a maximum CPU workload of 25% exclusively for ECDSA signature validation, we reached a maximum of 15 validations per 100 ms. We used 16, a slightly higher value, for dealing with multiples and sub-multiples of this value in further assessments considering different computational capabilities. Assuming a secure routing solution limited to a maximum of 16 beacon validations per 100 ms, we compared it with the case where there is no security overhead and all the beacons (the reference of 100% in Fig. 3) are consumed, naive routing. We present different results from a VANET perspective and from a device perspective. From the perspective of the exchanged beacons, Fig. 3 shows that, with secure routing, there are some periods where less beacons are consumed than with naive routing. There are two reasons for that: there are more useless beacons (i.e., beacons that do not give any useful route) and devices are not able to validate beacons before consuming them (during a 100ms window). Note that beacons without useful routing information do not need to be validated; therefore, all active devices that are more than 3 hops away from an RSU do not contribute to the variation of the percentage of useful beacons discarded due to ECDSA validation limitations. The devices discarding information are only the ones within the 3 hops limit. This figure reveals a correlation between the average number of neighbours (see Fig. 2) and the saturation of the validation process: with the increase of neighbours, there are more devices discarding at least one message with useful information. From the perspective of the impact on the routing service, Fig. 4 shows that, across the 24 h, the percentage of destinations that disappear from the VANET is always smaller than 3%, while the percentage of equivalent routes (i.e., routes to the same destination with the same number of hops and same quality) ranges from a maximum of 99% to a minimum of 53%. Non-optimum routes are the ones with more hops or the same number of hops but with lower transmission quality. The periods with the higher percentage of discarded beacons are coincident with the periods of smaller percentage of equivalent routes, which is an expected outcome. With individual routing awareness defined as the percentage of routes that are equivalent (i.e., same number of hops and same transmission quality) for both secure and naive routings, a complementary vision of the impact of ECDSA is given in Fig. 5. This figure shows the percentage of devices that are able to keep their individual awareness above a given threshold. This metric follows the approach defined by Schmidt et al. [45], where awareness is defined as “the relation between knowledge of vehicles that is stored in a vehicle’s neighbour table and the knowledge of vehicles that should be stored.” The represented percentiles of individual routing awareness show that a negative impact in Fig. 5 affects the VANET by affecting the majority of the devices. Although the maximum number of neighbours listened by a device is 57 (in our data set), with 48 validations per 100 ms there is no impact in the routing service. 5.1 Discussion The results obtained provide important insights and reveal that, without devices with a substantial computational power, ECDSA, and consequently IEEE 1609.2, would have a negative impact in the scenario that was tested, since it would be highly intrusive in the routing service of the tested VANET. This is particularly relevant since we considered a scenario with lower bounds to all requirements that could a priori avoid ECDSA to succeed. High-end CPUs, such as the ones used in personal computers, would allow a much higher number of validations and would be sustainable for the evaluated scenario, but such CPUs are not the ones commonly found in VANETs [17,25], neither they are a plausible option in our case. Furthermore, although powerful hardware could solve the ECDSA validation capability problem, we need to keep in mind that the workload of beacons’ authentication cannot rise above a limit that compromises all other services, such as the routing itself. 6 Conclusion In this paper, we evaluated the impact of authenticating WAVE messages according to IEEE 1609.2. Our evaluation focused in one particular VANET service, IP routing, and only in the authentication of the service’s control plane messages (beacons). For the evaluation we used mobility and communication traces captured from a city-scale VANET, we considered actual devices operating in that VANET and the best performance of multiple ECDSA implementations. We identified new and lower operational requirements where the computational overhead imposed by the ECDSA validation is a clear bottleneck for the communication process, with relevant consequences to the application using this validation. The obtained results reveal that, even with low demanding requirements, as the ones found in a sparse VANET, following IEEE 1609.2 would have a significant negative impact in the VANET’s routing service. Since this is a non-safety service, other solutions, such as using symmetric group shared keys (e.g., [46]), may be a better alternative than ECDSA to provide source authentication. Finally, the performance figures that we have calculated for ECDSA validations can be used in the future for evaluating the performance of protocols requiring vehicles’ authentication, such as fast electric charging of electric vehicles [47]. doc_title: Using reputation as a coin to bet on information items distributed in a smart city
doc_abstract: © 2019 IEEE.A key characteristic of Smart Cities is the ability to improve decision making by combining the maximum possible information provided by sensors or people. This paper presents a Blockchain-based reputation system for allowing citizens to assess the quality of information shared by other participating citizens. Citizens have the possibility to confirm or refute information posted by others, and the reputation of participants has a role in the final credibility of the information shared. Individual reputation is used as a 'currency', citizens bet with their reputation when giving an opinion, and get some reputation back when they are considered to be right. The reputation system is supervised by municipality stakeholders, which have the role of giving a final decision on the quality of the information and, consequently, in the update of the reputations associated with it. Stakeholders use Blockchain technology as a natural solution to spread their power regarding reputation management, ensuring a trustworthy dissemination of information, for instance, when reporting accidents.

doc_title: Smart crosswalks: A safe alert system that minimizes the confrontation between vehicles and pedestrians
doc_abstract: © 2019 IADIS Press. All rights reserved.A key characteristic of Smart Cities is the ability to reduce conflicts between different agents coexisting in a dynamic system, such as vehicles and pedestrians. This paper describes a system to augment the awareness of vehicle drivers regarding the presence of pedestrians in nearby crosswalks. To address this need, the system interconnects crosswalks to Road Side Units (RSUs), and RSUs to vehicles, in order to spread to vehicles the information about pedestrians in crosswalks. To prevent false information spreading, RSUs authenticate the alert messages they broadcast and all vehicles can validate them. This poses strong security requirements, such as non-repudiation of alert messages, as well as strong real-time requirements, such as minimum message propagation delays among vehicles approaching a crosswalk of interest. Because of this, the system minimizes the usage of asymmetric ciphers, which are fundamental to assure non-repudiation but increase performance penalties, and uses mostly symmetric ciphers for source authentication. To do so, we designed a new protocol, called Nimble Asymmetric Cryptography (NAC), which is useful to broadcast authenticated, implicit messages.

doc_title: Survey of passengers’ origin-destination in public transportation networks using WI-FI
doc_abstract: © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019.The knowledge of Origin-Destination (OD) locations of passengers using public transports is an important instrument to improve the service provided. In this paper, we describe a system that uses the passengers’ devices with an enabled Wi-Fi interface to track them along a transportation trip in order to infer OD information. The system does not require the cooperation of passengers other than having a device with an enabled Wi-Fi interface. The tracking system preserves the privacy of passengers, since no centrally stored raw data has any device-specific information. We deployed a prototype of the system in a bus of Porto’s public transportation network, which along several months collected 165161 passengers’ OD locations. A posterior analysis of the data gathered revealed the presence of false positives, which required the enforcement of filtering procedures in order to get values that are more reasonable for extracting relevant OD information. A comparison of bus occupancy loads of several weekdays during rush hours allowed us to find some patterns, which are an evidence of the correctness of the OD information extracted.

Various studies have indicated that for many large systems or pieces of equipment, maintenance and support account for as much as 60 to 75 percent of their overall life cycle costs, and sometimes much more. But even though the first book on maintainability, Electronic Maintainability, appeared in 1960, there are still only a handful of books available on the subject. doc_title: Usage of HTTPS by municipal websites in Portugal
doc_abstract: © Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019.This paper presents a study on the adoption of HTTPS in the official websites of all (308) Portuguese municipalities. Automated and, whenever needed, manual analysis were used to investigate its entry pages. Specifically, the pages were checked for the existence of an HTTPS site; the correctness of the certificates and their certification chain; coherence between contents of the HTTP and HTTPS sites; redirection between HTTP and HTTPS, HTTP resources fetched through HTTPS, and exploitation of HSTS. A final classification of municipalities was produced and possible determinants for the results were investigated. The general conclusion is that there is still much to be done in order to assure that citizens can communicate securely with all the Portuguese municipalities. Indeed, only 3.6% of the municipalities were considered good in this regard, while 46.1% do not guarantee the minimum conditions. These results seem to be associated with the dimension of the municipalities, although it was also identified the need for additional explanatory factors.

doc_title: Multi-technology vs Single-technology Architecture for Network Coding in VANETs
doc_abstract: © 2018 IEEE.The growing interest in vehicular networks (VANETs) is encouraging its deployment in new environments, for both safety applications and to provide Internet to its users. Vehicles can connect to others, or to the infrastructure, providing an Internet connection. The communication equipment placed inside the vehicles may have multiple network interfaces of diverse technologies, such as IEEE 802.11p/WAVE, IEEE 802.11a/g/n (Wi-Fi) and cellular. For this purpose, multihoming and network coding can be used to provide high bandwidth and reliability to these services, reducing packet losses due to poor wireless signal quality, therefore improving the final Quality-of-Service (QoS). This work evaluates the impact of a Systematic Network Coding (SNC) approach in multihoming when the coding is applied over traffic incoming from multiple technologies, or from a single technology, depending on the entity responsible for the encoding process. The multi-technology architecture proposed in this work will be evaluated using different coding configurations (generation and buffer sizes) and by analyzing its impact on the packet loss recovery ratio. The comparative results show that the multi-technology approach has a better delivery ratio when compared to the single-technology, despite the small impact on the packet delay.

doc_title: Fast, scalable and secure over-the-air bootstrap of Linux operating systems with Wi-Fi ad hoc networks
doc_abstract: © 2017, Springer Science+Business Media New York.This article describes and evaluates the performance of DETIboot, a system conceived for securely deploying temporary Linux systems into countless receiving hosts close enough to a Wi-Fi DETIboot server. This system was created with the ultimate goal of installing, in numerous students’ laptops and just-in-time, special Linux distributions for being temporarily used in practical classes. In this document we present an overview of DETIboot, a comprehensive description of the coding used in the broadcast communication and a detailed performance evaluation in a spacious auditorium. This evaluation did not involve security features to reduce the amount of variables influencing the final results. However, previous experiments allow us to extrapolate a maximum of 5% increase in the download time due to security. On average, it took us 50.1 s to download a 225 MiB Slax Linux over 802.11g, taking on average 15% more time than the theoretical lower bound of our setup (43.4 s). The influence of the position of receivers in the auditorium was not prominent.

doc_title: Vehicle-to-vehicle real-time video transmission through IEEE 802.11p for assisted-driving
doc_abstract: © 2018 IEEE.This work presents a V2V video transmission system to help on a car-overtaking decision using the IEEE 802.11p/WAVE communication technology. The system consists on a ffmpeg based video encoder that encapsulates the data received from a camera placed in a front vehicle into HTTP Post packets, and forwards the packet to the rear vehicle through the On Board Units (OBUs) installed on both vehicles. The rear vehicle presents the images to the driver using a visualization device. The proposed system was evaluated through real vehicular experiments in two distinct scenarios: Urban and highway. Performance studies were focused on delay measurements, re- transmission rate, signal strength and bandwidth consumption related with the traveling speeds and video quality. Results show that the communication delay is higher in the highway scenario, mainly due to the distance between vehicles and the different speeds. However, promising results regarding the maximum delay and the average number of retransmissions foresee important inputs for future services of assisted-driving, in general, and car- overtaking assistance, in particular.

doc_title: A propose for a federated ledger for regulated self-sovereignty
doc_abstract: © 2018 AISTI.In a world where people must subject themselves to high scrutiny in every process they initiate, and in a world where the digital environment grows incessantly, we anticipate more online services asking for personal attributes and their need to trust in such attributes. For tackling such need, we will describe a proposal for a secure, decentralized and shared repository of certified personal attributes. Service providers, which are the entities that need to gather such attributes, can benefit from a proper certification by the entities responsible for them. The certifying entities can benefit, because they retain the power to revoke previously issued certifications. Finally, individuals benefit because they have full control over the disclosure of their set of certified personal attributes, namely to service providers, in order to assert their identity.

doc_title: TROPHY: Trustworthy VANET routing with group authentication keys
doc_abstract: © 2017 Elsevier B.V.Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) are a specific case of ad hoc networks where most of the nodes are vehicles. VANETs have emerged in the last few years and are likely to play a major role in the future for a wide number of applications. Routing is essential for any ad hoc network, thus security strategies for protecting VANETs’ routing are critical. In this paper we present TROPHY (Trustworthy VANET ROuting with grouP autHentication keYs), a set of protocols to manage the authentication of routing messages in a VANET, under highly demanding time conditions, capable of protecting the distribution of routing information, considering the WAVE architecture and the patented routing approach, the Service-Based Layer-2 Routing Protocol. Authorised nodes recursively receive TROPHY messages that allow them to refresh their cryptographic material and keep authentication keys updated across the network. Those messages are epidemically distributed across the network and built such that any node pinpointed as lost or physically compromised will not be able to perform the refreshment using them (and so, are excluded from the routing process). Due to the use of a Key Distribution Centre (KDC), a central entity, where all the cryptographic material is stored, we included a mechanism to recover from any unauthorised physical access and disclosure of all such material at once, without requiring the need of human intervention on devices’ re-setup.
