Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) are a specific case of ad hoc networks where most of the nodes are vehicles. VANETs have emerged in the last few years and are likely to play a major role in the future for a wide number of applications. Routing is essential for any ad hoc network, thus security strategies for protecting VANETs’ routing are critical. In this paper we present TROPHY (Trustworthy VANET ROuting with grouP autHentication keYs), a set of protocols to manage the authentication of routing messages in a VANET, under highly demanding time conditions, capable of protecting the distribution of routing information, considering the WAVE architecture and the patented routing approach, the Service-Based Layer-2 Routing Protocol. Authorised nodes recursively receive TROPHY messages that allow them to refresh their cryptographic material and keep authentication keys updated across the network. Those messages are epidemically distributed across the network and built such that any node pinpointed as lost or physically compromised will not be able to perform the refreshment using them (and so, are excluded from the routing process). Due to the use of a Key Distribution Centre (KDC), a central entity, where all the cryptographic material is stored, we included a mechanism to recover from any unauthorised physical access and disclosure of all such material at once, without requiring the need of human intervention on devices’ re-setup. Keywords Secure routing Group keys Epidemic propagation 1 Introduction Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) are a class of ad hoc networks that inherit most of the characteristics of Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs), but still, with enough differences to define a new category by itself [1–3]. VANETs may have hundreds or thousands of nodes equipped with wireless communication capabilities. Most of the nodes are devices carried by vehicles, On Board Units (OBUs), and a relatively small part of the nodes are devices statically placed near roads, equipped with wired communication capabilities, Road Side Units (RSUs). By their very singular nature and requirements, when compared with MANETs [4,5], the academic research community has given an increasingly amount of attention to the topic. Those characteristics have also lead to the creation of VANETs’ specific solutions, such as the Wireless Access in Vehicular Environment (WAVE) architecture [6]. VANETs are intrinsically associated to safety applications due to the possibility of saving human-lives [7]. Nevertheless, besides safety applications, VANETs also support non-safety applications [8] such as comfort applications, which allow passengers to receive contextualised information (e.g. tourist and city leisure information), and interactive entertainment applications, which allow users to interact either with the Internet or among each other (e.g. Web browsing and file sharing) [9]. Routing strategies to support unicast communications among vehicles have being considered in VANETs since a long time [10–12] and are essential to support IP connectivity [13], thus security strategies for protecting VANETs’ routing must be considered essential. However, in the VANETs’ routing context, it is not possible to apply classical techniques, such as handshake-based authentication protocols [1]; therefore, some common security problems, such as availability, secrecy and integrity, do not have a widely accepted solution. The widely accepted WAVE architecture defines a set of complementary and interdependent protocols to operate in a VANET environment [6,14]. The IEEE 1609.2 [15] standard defines methods and formats of secure messages. For routing services, the IEEE 1609.2 standard may lead to service deficiencies [16], mainly due to message validation delays caused by asymmetric cryptography; as we will see, this is the case of our target VANET. 1.1 Motivation The main objective of our work is to add security to the routing protocols in VANETs, such as the Veniam’s VANET in Porto, which has more than 600 VANET Units (VUs) [17]. The VUs in operation are somewhat limited, in both memory and CPU, when compared with an average personal computer, and the impact of asymmetric cryptographic operations, such as the ones conceived for WAVE, is not negligible. This VANET uses a routing protocol named Service-Based Layer-2 Routing Protocol (SB2RP) [18], which was designed to work under very strict time constraints while providing Internet access to passengers in buses. Such constraints made us decide for the use of symmetric cryptography and network-wide authentication keys to tackle the authentication of legitimate traffic. The use of network-wide authentication keys raises several management issues, namely keys must be refreshed after a specific time of use, to prevent their cryptanalysis, and there must be a solution to deal with the leakage of such keys upon the compromise of one or more VUs. For that purpose, we developed Trustworthy VANET ROuting with grouP autHentication keYs (TROPHY), a set of protocols to manage the distribution of authentication keys among authorised VUs in the VANET. Furthermore, we decided not to add a new independent set of protocols to the existing ones in the VANET, but rather to piggyback TROPHY messages within the already existent routing messages. Although the connectivity of a VANET, especially OBUs’ connectivity, can be complemented with other technologies, such as cellular networks, we focus on making our solution only dependent of the ad hoc network. 1.2 Contributions We assume that there are two types of candidates to participate in the routing process, authorised and unauthorised ones. Unauthorised devices shall not interfere in the VANET routing process, while authorised ones are all those that were initially prepared to operate in the VANET. It is assumed that all the authorised devices work properly. Within the unauthorised, we have all the devices not belonging to the VANET, as well as any device previously authorised but after some date pinpointed as lost or physically compromised. Consequently, we seek to authenticate all routing messages in order to defeat any adversary with the aim to modify or destroy the routing process and full capabilities to eavesdrop, store, modify and transmit an arbitrary number of valid messages. Moreover, we seek to provide mechanisms to overcome attackers with the power to get physical access to one or more devices and all the cryptographic material stored on them, as well as mechanisms to recover from the disclosure of all cryptographic material stored on a central server. The main contribution of this article is the specification and evaluation of TROPHY, a set of protocols to manage the authentication of routing messages in a VANET. TROPHY honours the real and well-defined requirements of our target VANET and does not destroy its original routing strategy by excessively consuming time or resources. More specially, the characteristics of TROPHY are the following: • To operate under highly restrictive time conditions, especially in a large group of limited computational devices, and to be able to protect the distribution of routing information from external attackers, TROPHY uses symmetric cryptography in the most frequent operations. • To recover from the real possibility of any of the devices to get stolen, lost, damaged or becoming suspicious, TROPHY relies on the logical arrangement of the devices and several symmetric group keys in a binary tree structure, in order to exclude any set of nodes at any time with a relatively small quantity of information exchanged in the network. • To mitigate the impact of an arbitrary number of compromised nodes deployed in a large area and uncontrolled environment, TROPHY makes use of a Key Distribution Centre (KDC) to control all the critical processes, as well as to store all the associated sensitive data. • To minimise the needs of direct contact by the devices with the central entity, TROPHY enforces that the messages produced by the KDC can be shared among devices without requiring a mutual trust among them. • To maximise the effective rate of exchanged information among devices with sporadic and highly volatile connections, TROPHY uses handshakeless communications, with its messages piggybacked, on a needed basis, in the routing protocol messages. • To be resilient to the disclosure of all the essential content kept the KDC at once, TROPHY is prepared to recover without requiring the need of human intervention on each of the devices for their re-setup. The results obtained with trace-based emulations using real information samples show that authorised routing messages can be authenticated with Message Authentication Codes (MACs) and a relatively small number of messages signed by a KDC. Moreover, the results show that an epidemic propagation (among the OBUs) of the messages produced by the KDC can, efficiently and on a needed basis, update hundreds of devices in service in a area of approximately 400km2, with a minimal intervention of the KDC and the RSUs. This article is organised as follows: Section 2 introduces the context where TROPHY will operate. Section 3 provides a high-level overview of different approaches to transmit secure messages in VANETs and an overview of different strategies to manage group keys. Section 4 describes the proposed architecture of our solution. Section 5 contextualises the tests scenarios and aggregates the correspondent results. Conclusions are drawn in Section 6. 2 Context Our work is based on Veniam’s VANET and its characteristics, currently deployed in Porto city, Portugal. In our scenario, both OBUs and RSUs are devices with the same hardware and exactly the same computational power. They are the 4th generation of hardware used by the company in real scenarios, equipped with an ARM Cortex-A7 CPU (i.MX 6 at 800MHz) and running a Linux kernel to support a small set of tools. The time needed to verify a signature using Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) with 224 bits is about 5.7 milliseconds. Alternative scenarios, with computationally more powerful RSUs, were not considered. From the point of view of an ad hoc network, the routing strategy in VANETs has to deal with some new challenges, even when compared with MANETs [19,20]. The routing strategy in use, SB2RP, was developed to face all the challenges found during its deployment. The strategy relies on both V2I and V2V communications to create IP routes between the OBUs and the RSUs; those routes can be either directly or indirectly through multiple hops (RSUs have IP-based communication with an infrastructure). SB2RP is a WAVE application associated to the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) data link layer (layer 2) that implements a periodic distance-vector routing algorithm to route between the infrastructure and the VANET (communication to and from the infrastructure). Besides the operation on the OSI layer 2, SB2RP has direct access to the routing tables of IP, associated to the OSI Layer 3. The routing service is identified by a Provider Service Identifier (PSID) and the messages are broadcasted according to the WAVE Short Message Protocol (WSMP) in periods of 100 milliseconds. The relevant information for this work exchanged in those beacons is: the Global Positioning System (GPS) information, the local time, and the routing information. Each VU stores the information received on the SB2RP messages for each of the neighbours in an auxiliary table. Each time a new SB2RP message is received, any older information related with the same origin is replaced. All the entries on the auxiliary table are removed if older than 1.5 seconds. The IP routing tables are updated, conditionally to the neighbours in a range of 3 hops, in periods of 1 second, upon the information stored on the auxiliary table. This is possible due to a direct relation between the identification of the VU and the IP address of that VU. SB2RP does not have into consideration any security aspects. However, SB2RP may filter out incoming routing messages based on their time stamp (too different from the local one), GPS position (too far away) or any other parameter, before using them to update the routing tables. The algorithms proposed on the IEEE 1609.2 standard are not compatible with the operation mode of SB2RP. This incompatibility can be deduced by taking as reference the time needed for the verification of a signature using ECDSA and the 100 milliseconds period to exchange routing information. Due to the time-related constraints, this incompatibility is extended to all the strategies based on similar asymmetric cryptographic primitives. The use of 100% of the CPU, or even 50%, to validate routing messages is not acceptable, and still it would just be possible to validate 17 or 8 messages per 100 milliseconds. Moreover, SB2RP would be highly susceptible to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. Although the computational limitation presented is related with the specific hardware actually in use, especially its CPU and the absence of a cryptoprocessor, this limitation is not exclusive from our target hardware, but rather common to alternative devices designed to operate in VANETs [21]. Notably, in the EVITA project [22], Wolf et al. [23] developed a vehicular hardware-accelerated security module where a 256-bit ECDSA verification takes 2.2 ms. Moreover, the use of IEEE 1609.2 is not only time-consuming in terms of signature verification, but also bandwidth-consuming due to the appended signature and certificate [24–26], since each secure beacon must always be sent with a signature and the sender certificate [15]. Using implicit certificates, the shortest type of certificates allowed in the standard [15], and considering ECDSA with 224 bits, each beacon has 84 extra bytes [27] plus certification information. For the same level of security strength [28] our MAC has only 16 bytes. 3 Related work The WAVE architecture [6] allows the transmission of secure messages based on the IEEE 1609.2 standard [15], which for authentication relies on ECDSA asymmetric signatures. As previously referred, we did not follow this standard since the use of ECDSA, to sign each routing message, would be a serious limitation to the number of processed messages. Furthermore, the signature of a percentage of them would end up on a non-deterministic behaviour, and the production of one signature for groups of more than one routing message, would create critical time and contextual dependencies between the mobile nodes. The limitations imposed by ECDSA (asymmetric primitives in general) are not only associated to IEEE 1609.2 but rather common to Public Key Infrastructures (PKIs), such as the one proposed by Carter et al. [29]. In our solution we do not use asymmetric primitives to authenticate the messages exchanged among VUs and the KDC replaces the PKI. Nevertheless, we use the ECDSA to authenticate, in the VUs, some messages produced by the KDC. In this case, the time needed to produce the signature is not critical, since it is done sporadically by a distinct and powerful machine, neither it is the time needed to validate the signature in VUs, due to the sparse periods of this process. With a focus on broadcast authentication, Perrig et al. [30] [31] proposed a solution where asymmetry is obtained based on time synchronisation and successive disclosure of keys in well determined periods. In short, the sender first sends a message with a MAC, and it later discloses the key and starts using a new one. With the message, the MAC and later the key, any receiver can validate the MAC. Assuming time synchronisation between the participants, with the use of one-way functions it is possible to ensure that a disclosed key is not a valid key to create new MACs. Some variations were created for specific scenarios, such as Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) [32] and VANETs [16], but none was used in the routing context. The variation proposed by Studer et al. [16] has in common with our solution the goal to avoid the digital asymmetric signatures associated to the WAVE architecture due to time related constraints. However, this solution needs a large number of keys being stored in each device, the same number of keys as the number of devices in the VANET. Moreover, due to the use of a pre-computed chain of values resultant from a one-way function, all the devices need to be loaded periodically with a new chain and a public starting point of the chain of all the other devices. In our case, we have a small number of keys stored in each device, and there is no need for periodic, global and synchronised re-setups in all the devices. Ahmed et al. [33] and Wagan et al. [34] presented two distinct solutions based on the geographical division of the region accessible by the OBUs into smaller areas. The division can be recursive, so, the smaller areas can be, by their own, divided into even smaller areas. Both proposals, also due to time related constrains, have as goal to avoid the digital asymmetric signatures associated to the WAVE architecture. In each area, there is one or more RSUs or a group leader elected among OBUs, responsible for the registration and the delivery of the correspondent keys and certificates to the new OBUs entering the area. Both solutions make use of symmetric cryptography to speed up the message authentication for high priority emergency messages [33] or for communications inside a small area [34]. Besides the use of symmetric cryptography, in an abstract way, there is another common idea between these two proposed architectures and our own: the use of a hierarchy to facilitate the management of the VANET, regarding the distribution of new cryptographic material. However, instead of groups associated to a geographical area, we have groups based on a virtual, geographical-independent hierarchy, where OBUs are free to be dispersed among the available region and use a common symmetric key for the entire region. Instead of a dependence on the geographical area, we have a dependence on time, so, the key associated to the authentication of routing messages is different from time to time and not from local to local. With a time-dependent process, in which there is a different routing key for different time periods, we need a mechanism to timely distribute new security-relevant information to all the devices in a wide area, otherwise they will be unable to communicate among each other. We considered an epidemic distribution process, that in VANETs has received quite some attention in the past and was mainly being investigated for distributing Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs) [35–37]. However, unlike the distribution of the CRLs, we distribute information that will invalidate an old key and generate a new key. Another difference is the fact that to exclude devices, instead of a unique CRL that has to be received by all the non-excluded devices, we distribute to the VANET multiple and independent messages. Therefore, each of the non-excluded devices will just need a single message to update itself (even if it can collect and redistribute all the other messages to the global benefit of the VANET). In addition, by the symmetric nature of the key, to prevent its cryptanalysis we need to update it and not only when devices need to be excluded (as with CRLs). 3.1 Group keys A group key is a cryptographic key shared among a group of entities. All entities with access to the group key can use it to encrypt or authenticate (and perform the respectively reverse operation) all the transmitted messages among them via an insecure channel, following a one-to-many or a many-to-many paradigm. The topic of group keys started to receive attention from network researchers in late 1990s, due to the prediction of future needs related with multicast services based on group communications model [38–41], e.g. teleconference, information services. According to the architecture in use, group key management is currently classified according to three main approaches [42–47]: Centralised: There is a single entity responsible for the management of the group. Decentralised: There are multiple entities responsible for the management of subgroups of the main group. Distributed or contributory: There is no central neither decentralised entity. The members of a group are responsible for the management. They can contribute to the computations or elect (be elected by) any of the peers to perform such task. Considering our well-defined scenario, the centralised approach is the one that best fits our requirements. Therefore, we will focus our analysis on the different approaches within the centralised category. Under a centralised architecture, the creation and revocation of keys are responsibility of a single entity, a KDC. A group key distribution protocol is used to make available to all the members of a group the needed secret key, or keys. Relatively to the centralised category, we did not focus on schemes based solely on pairwise keys, where the KDC and each of the V members of the group only share an individual secret and the distribution of a new key always relies on V rekeying messages [38]. Nevertheless, we used pairwise keys for dealing with special circumstances (see Section 4.2.2). Excluding the schemes exclusively based on pairwise key schemes, all the rest of the centralised approaches fall into a hierarchical organization, based on graphs, and trees as a specific case (See Fig. 1 ). On this type of organization, group members, at the lowest level, have a collection of keys: all the keys in the path from the lowest node until the root node. In Fig. 1 the group key is k 1234. The other keys are used to distribute the new keys. For example, if ciphered with k 1234, a new key is available for all the members, but when ciphered with k 12 it is just available to u 1 and u 2. Graphs in which two vertices are connected by more than one path are rarely used in literature; and when they are, the authors end up removing some paths and getting better results with the resultant trees [41]. Although we do not consider schemes based solely on pairwise keys, tree-based hierarchies guarantee that there is a key shared exclusively between each node and the KDC, so one of the options available (though not the only one) is a pairwise key. Tree-based hierarchies were independently proposed by Wong et al. [41] and D. Wallner et al. [39]. Before these proposals, according to Wong et al. [41], “no one has addressed the need for frequent key changes and the associated scalability problem for a very large group” with a globally shared group key. Those initial works have been proposed with wired connections, multicast and a one-to-many communication paradigm in mind. This is a crucial difference, since the characteristics of ad hoc networks, VANETs in special, create additional challenges [44,48]. Moreover, since we are using the group key to authenticate messages between members and not to guarantee the secrecy of any data, we can relax our needs on the so-called backward secrecy [49,50]. Wong et al. [41] formalises three types of strategies to update the keys on members: User-Oriented: where each member receives a specific single message with the new keys, ciphered with a key held by the members. Key-Oriented: where each of the new keys are ciphered individually, and so, members may need more than one message. Group-Oriented: where all messages are concatenated in a single message, sent to all members, which will later select the needed keys. Key-Oriented and Group-Oriented imply that all members need to receive more than one message or a relatively big message, respectively, thus they are not suitable for our scenario. We followed a hybrid model, using a User-Oriented strategy in a minor number of cases, and an approach that takes the best of both User-Oriented and the Key-Oriented strategies. The majority of the key updates are performed building a relatively small number of ciphered messages, where all members will find one that can decipher, and use the content to update (refresh) all keys. An update method, based on a refreshment, called synchro-difference, was firstly proposed by Zhu [51], where instead of distributing new keys, it is distributed a single key update used by the members to produce all the new keys. The distributed key update contains a common difference between the old key and the new one to be produced. Taking the tree in the right hand size of Fig. 1 as example, if u 4 is compromised, in a User-Oriented strategy, u 1 and u 2 would receive the same message with the new k 1234 ciphered with the k 12, and u 3 receives a distinct message with both k 1234 and k 34 ciphered with k 3. In a Key-Oriented strategy, u 1 and u 2 would receive the same message, but u 3 needs 2 messages: one with the new k 34 ciphered with k 3, and another with the new k 1234 ciphered with the new k 34. With a synchro-difference, u 1 and u 2 would receive some random value ciphered with k 12, and u 3 would receive the same random value ciphered with k 3. Each of the new keys is produced based on a bitwise exclusive-or (XOR) of the old key and the received random value. Canetti et al. [52] presented a different way to reduce the overhead of messages in the network. Instead of a key update used to generate all new keys, it is used a one-way function, H(x), to give to the different members the results of different number of chained iterations over the one-way function. Each of the members can then compute all the keys it is entitled to have. The authors give only as example the exclusion of only one member, although it is possible to generalise the strategy and conclude that the exclusion of multiple members at once can only be endured by the successive exclusion of one at a time. Based on a synchro-difference, we can exclude multiple members at once. Sherman et al. [53] extended the idea of Canetti et al. [52] from a one-way function to one-way trees, also known as Merkle trees [54]. A solution based on one-way trees allows multiple exclusions at a time, but needs the management and distribution of an extra value associated to each of the nodes, a so-called blind key. The blind key is built upon the secret key of the sibling of each node. By sibling, we mean the node that shares the same ascendant. This enables each node to calculate the common ascendant without breaking the secrecy of its sibling’s secret key. Perrig et al. [55] presented a work focused on “secure media broadcast over the internet” where the KDC and all members have synchronised time and where both can, in some occasions, independently update the keys in well-defined periods. This can be seen as a virtual distribution protocol of the new keys, where no messages need to be sent between entities. In common with this idea, we have the notion of periodic updates, but in our case, with an explicit distribution of new messages. The idea of synchronisation with no messages was initially attractive and considered, but we concluded that an epidemic propagation of the key updates would be a better way to fit our requirements, since with it we are not dependent on scheduled events that may occur in a different context in the future. Dini et al. [56] proposed the use of one-way functions to provide self-authenticated, key-oriented updates for efficient key revocation, avoiding the use of digital signatures in update messages. A key k can be obtained by k = H ( k n x t ) , where H(x) is a one-way function and knxt is the next key received on a ciphered message. With this approach, each member can test the newly received key, which was delivery ciphered but without any type of signature. However, to the best of our knowledge, this cannot be applied along with our method where we send a difference to all keys of the next generation. Thus, using Key-Oriented updates to have benefit of this strategy was not considered worthy. Perrig et al. [55], Ng et al. [57] and Park et al. [58] proposed different hierarchical schemes based on unbalanced and dynamic balanced trees, with the aim to constantly optimise the structure according to the volatile number of members. In contrast, we use a static and permanently balanced tree, prepared to accommodate a pre-defined large number of members. Instead of rearranging the tree structure each time new members join or leave the group, we use a strategy, with negligible effect in both storage and processing needs, to identify the impact of these actions on the pre-accommodated nodes and consider only their existence on a needed basis. Thus, we end up with the same benefits as if the tree was being constantly re-balanced. 4 Architecture The TROPHY architecture is influenced by multiple trade-offs related with the acceptable overhead, costs and complexity (both human-related and computational) introduced by extra policies and protocol layers, and correspondent effectiveness. Since VANETs may contain thousands of devices, we focused in minimising the need for individual intervention along the time in each device, as well as restrict the impact that actions associated to one device may have among all the others. Moreover, the real time requirements of the routing protocol in operation, allied to the available hardware, limited the use of asymmetric cryptographic primitives. Considering all this, we started by designing an architecture based on a shared group identity. By shared group identity, we mean that members will not recognise each other by their individual identity but rather by a global, common identity. With a shared group identity, we can clearly distinguish between authorised and unauthorised group members, and so, we started by exploring an authentication mechanism among authorised group members based on symmetric cryptographic primitives. Due to the vulnerabilities associated to such approach, especially if any of the members is captured by an attacker or simply lost, we considered that neither an individual member nor a subgroup of members should be in charge of any aspect related with the control of the group identity (e.g. decide who must be included or excluded from the group). Therefore, a distinct, unique and centralised entity was introduced to take this responsibility, the KDC. Such entity stores and controls the shared group identity as well as each of the members’ identity. The introduction of the KDC raised new trade-offs by its own, mainly associated to the security of the stored data and the transmission of new information to each of the members. If, from one hand, a fast transmission of information would be beneficial for the global state of the VANET, from the other hand, the ad hoc infrastructure may not guarantee such requirement, and so, costly solutions could have to be introduced, e.g. the use of cellular networks. To avoid costly solutions and assuming that the ad hoc infrastructure cannot guarantee a fast transmission of information for all the members, neither should it be flooded to achieve such goal, we followed the approach of an opportunistic and epidemic propagation. With this approach members receive new information according to a best effort policy followed by all the VANET members, without the need of mutual trust among any members. Thus, symmetric cryptography is used to authenticate messages exchanged among members and asymmetric cryptography is used to sign contents produced by the KDC. In the best effort policy are considered both individual computational resources and global bandwidth consumption. Computational resources’ consumption is reduced due to the extensive use of symmetric cryptography, while the impact of both asymmetric cryptography in members and bandwidth consumption in the network can be dynamically adjusted through the KDC by updating and disseminating the parameters that influence the best effort policy. Since the shared group identity is at risk if any member gets physically compromised, with the benefits of a centralised entity, the KDC, we implemented a mechanism to efficiently exclude any set of members while updating the shared group identity only to the remaining trusted ones. Moreover, we complemented TROPHY with a mechanism to recover from an attack to the KDC and consequent disclosure of all the information related with the control of both group and members’ identity. The next subsections detail the proposed approach. 4.1 Overview In detail, TROPHY architecture has 4 entities: a KDC, its human operator, the OBUs and the RSUs. We may indistinctly mention both OBUs and RSUs as a single entity, the VUs. The KDC is responsible for creating, updating, and periodically initiating the distribution of messages needed to maintain the routing authentication process valid across the network. The KDC was prepared to interact with a human operator, to setup the network as well as to update some parameters based on decisions taken during its operation. All the orders produced by the KDC are initially sent in messages to one or more RSUs, and then disseminated by all of them to all the others, following an opportunistic and epidemic approach. All the TROPHY messages are piggybacked in the messages of the routing protocol in operation, SB2RP 1 1 Since SB2RP uses WSMP messages that can be transmitted in any of the WAVE channels [8], TROPHY itself is agnostic to the channel in use. . Taking this in consideration, we focused in the creation of small messages. Besides making the messages small in the number of bytes, we also focused in reducing the number of occurrences of all those messages. 4.2 Interaction between entities The human operator can, at any time, include or exclude new VUs, as well as to reconfigure some network-wide parameters in the KDC. After the initial setup of VUs by a human operator, the routing process is initiated on those VUs. The routing messages exchanged between VUs, known as beacons, are authenticated with a MAC created with the routing key, ρ, a symmetric key shared by all VUs. The routing key is periodically refreshed by the KDC to anticipate its potential cryptanalysis, given the high number of MACs that may be created with the same key during the VANET operation. Furthermore, if one or more VUs are pinpointed as lost or physically compromised, the human operator can immediately launch a key refreshment to prevent the exploitation of a possible leaked routing key. The refreshment process is also used to exclude the compromised VUs thereafter from the VANET’s routing (the VUs to exclude are not involved in the key refreshment process). When we mention ρ, we mention the routing key without taking in consideration a specific refreshment associated to a time interval. The multiple refreshments of ρ create a sequence of values identifiable as ρ ( 1 ) , ρ ( 2 ) , ρ ( 3 ) , … , ρ ( t − 1 ) , ρ ( t ) , ρ ( t + 1 ) . The time for the key updates in the VANET is controlled by the KDC under the form of time intervals with consecutive indexes. The time intervals are associated to the real time of the KDC, and each of the intervals may have a different duration. Each VU uses the most recent index to compare itself with the rest of the VANET, e.g. if a VU with ρ(t) receives an update message associated to t + 2 , it can deduce that an update message associated to t + 1 already circulated in the VANET. If otherwise we had updates with absolute time-stamps, the VUs could not take conclusions about the existence of any other intermediate updates between them unless there was a well-defined period for the KDC to release new updates. However, strictly periodic updates would prevent arbitrary update decisions, and so, are not desirable. For this reason, even with the absolute time present in beacons and available for routing decisions based on minimum clock synchronisation between VUs, the update of ρ in the VANET is not dependent on it. The VUs may have different versions of ρ as their most recent routing key. Each VU will always use the most recent version of ρ to create and validate MACs. Beacons are only used to update the routing information if they have a valid MAC computed with the most recent version of ρ present on the receiver. Beacons with valid MACs computed with older versions of ρ are only used to trigger the update process in updated neighbours. On each VU, the most recent version of ρ is also used to create and verify MACs for all the exchanged IP packets being routed. During the reception of the packets, they are discarded if the MAC is invalid or associated with an old version of ρ. 4.2.1 Epidemic propagation of key refreshments The refreshment of ρ is performed based on a refreshment update, r(t), sent by the KDC to the VANET. Such updates are signed by the KDC with its private, asymmetric key, and all VUs can validate the signature with the correspondent public key that was initially preloaded. The signed refreshment update, together with some auxiliary information, forms a refreshment message. The signature of refreshment messages by the KDC and the validation of such signatures by VUs are the only parts of the process requiring asymmetric cryptography. Refreshment messages are associated to a specific time interval, t, and always have as first destination the RSUs. For the same time interval t, there may exist one or more distinct refreshment messages and each message carries this distinct number on it. RSUs periodically contact the KDC and receive the new messages, if any. From RSUs, the refreshment messages are redistributed to all OBUs within beacons. After receiving a refreshment message, OBUs can redistribute it to all neighbour OBUs, in the exactly same way the RSUs initially did. This way, we have an epidemic propagation of the refreshment messages, where VUs do not have to trust on each other to receive and validate contents created by KDC. Moreover, we have a process completely controlled by KDC (which decides when updates need to occur), whereas most of the work is delegated to VUs, following a best effort approach. In Fig. 2 we have a basic scenario to illustrate the epidemic propagation of the refreshment messages, associated to r(1), and its use to update ρ(0) to ρ(1) in RSUs and OBUs. The epidemic key refreshment is a chained process where VUs can only update its cryptographic material to the last state t, based on the previous state t − 1 . The use of a chained process, instead of a direct replacement, has one main advantage: the same refreshment message can be used to refresh different keys at the same time on different VUs without breaking the secrecy of such keys. This is especially useful since the routing key ρ is not the only symmetric key used in the VANET. In groups of VUs that were not isolated from the VANET, each VU has the required routing key to create MACs for its own beacons and to validate the ones received from neighbours. We considered a VU isolated if, in case of an OBU, it moves out of the VANET coverage area or if it is simply powered off and unable to communicate with other VUs for some period. Notably, parked vehicles are not a cause of isolation, since OBUs can still operate and interact with the VANET when parked [37,59]. After an isolation period, a VU may be required to engage on a specific key update before being able to participate again on the routing process with its neighbours. Such key update is supported by updated neighbouring VUs, based on an historical cache of the last refreshment messages stored on such neighbours. The size of the cache, h, is measured in time intervals and is controlled by the KDC. Any updated VU can contribute to the update of a peer, by sending cached information previously received. To improve the spreading of all the distinct refreshment messages across the VANET, each VU includes in its beacons the status, either complete or not, of its historical cache. If all the VUs are updated, but some have their historical cache incomplete, neighbours can detect the situation and append to its next beacon a refreshment message from its cache, selected randomly. Based on the incompleteness of the neighbours, VUs can append refreshment messages to a limited percentage of the transmitted beacons, instead of doing it for all of them. This percentage, the basal refreshment rate, brr, is defined by the KDC and is the same for all VUs. Along with a new refreshment, the KDC can redefine brr. Unfortunately, an isolated VU remains unable to participate on the routing process when none of the neighbours has the needed refreshment messages on their historical cache. This calls for an alternative method to deal with this extreme situation. 4.2.2 Fallback after a period of isolation If one VU is isolated or powered off, it may lose one or more refreshment messages. Furthermore, the VU can be explicitly isolated by the KDC. Mainly because of the first case, a fallback method is necessary to update its routing key, since it is desirable that the VU reengages on the routing process. On the second case, the isolation must be honoured, and the fallback must only work after some explicit decision that cancels the previous state of isolation. The RSUs can directly exchange messages with the KDC at any time; so, if allowed, an RSU can easily recover the last state of the cryptographic material of the VANET. The OBUs, on the other hand, do not have such possibility. If an OBU cannot be updated by the content on the historical cache of its neighbours, it can use an RSU as proxy to request a specific message to synchronise its routing key with the value present in the KDC. These requests, sync message requests, contain the last time interval known by the OBU, and 2 MACs, one created with ρ and the other one created with a key, ϵ, shared only by the KDC and the OBU. The first MAC can be used to filter requests on RSUs. The second is used to authenticate the OBU in the KDC. The replies, sync message replies, contain all the keys for the VU, encrypted with an ϵ and signed by the KDC. In Fig. 3 we illustrate this protocol, where neither the OBU nor the KDC have to trust on the intermediate RSU. After a period of isolation, and upon detecting an RSU, an OBU ν appends to its beacon a sync request, Rν , which will be sent to the KDC by an RSU. After receiving a sync reply, Uν (t), the RSU will append it to its next beacon. The sync reply will be available to all the neighbours of the RSU, but can only be decrypted by the OBU ν. All the neighbours of the RSU also resend Uν (t), appending it to a beacon. If ν gets out of range of the RSU during the time to process the reply in the KDC, it may still be able to receive Uν (t) by an intermediate OBU. The resending process only occurs when Uν (t) comes from an RSU and not when it comes from an OBU. In the case of RSUs, the process is similar, but simpler, since there is no need of any intermediate entity. RSUs can do their own update requests and this is not visible by the neighbours, since there is no impact on transmitted beacons. When receiving a beacon with a sync request appended and a MAC created with an older ρ ( ρ ( t − n ) in Fig. 3), the RSU may or may not have such old ρ version. The verification of the MAC by the RSU is not mandatory; it may be only performed when instructed by the KDC to do so (e. g. upon starting receiving invalid sync requests). In case this validation is needed, if the old value of ρ is not present in the RSU, the value is sent by the KDC. 4.2.3 Human operator and VANET The human operator can control the VANET through the KDC. Some operational parameters can be redefined to fit new requirements: Default refreshment period: Although refreshments can be sent to VANET at any time, we enforce a minimum period if no action is taken by the operator. Historical cache size: h, the limit for the old refreshments stored on VUs (see Section 4.2.1). This value is always sent along with all the new refreshment messages. Basal refreshment rate: brr, the percentage of beacons that can carry a refreshment message for updating neighbours with an incomplete cache (see Section 4.2.1). This value is sent along within refreshment messages. Complementary, some actions can be taken to manage the VANET: Include new VUs: The cryptographic material is loaded from the KDC to the device. This is transparent to the rest of the VANET and does not trigger any new refreshment. Exclude compromised VUs: The exclusion of VUs immediately triggers a new refreshment of the VANET keys (see Section 4.3.1). Resurrect compromised VUs: In the KDC a new exclusive key ϵ for the VU is generated and stored, and then loaded into the device (see Section 4.3.1). Reset all keys on VANET: In case of all the VANET distribution keys in the KDC got disclosed (a major disaster!) new ones will be generated. Moreover, a reset message is immediately sent to the VANET; it will allow all the VUs to recover without any need of human intervention on its hardware (see Section 4.3.2). This recover is only possible if the private key of the KDC has not been compromised. 4.3 Cryptographic material With the exception of an asymmetric key pair belonging to the KDC, all other keys used in the VANET are symmetric keys. The private key of the KDC is used to sign all the contents sent to the VANET; the public key is preloaded on all its VUs. On Section 4.2 we mentioned a key, the routing key ρ, known by all VUs, used to create and validate MACs of beacons and routed traffic. We also mentioned a key, the exclusive key ϵ, shared by each of the VUs and the KDC, used to exchange secret information between the KDC and each VU. The exclusive keys of all VUs form the set of exclusive keys E. The components of E are initialised with random values (seeds). Those values remain unchangeable along the different time intervals: (1) E ( t + 1 ) = E ( t ) For the secure distribution of the refreshment messages across the VANET, we use n auxiliary group keys, which form the set of group keys G. The components of G are associated to a time interval t: (2) G ( t ) = ⋃ i = 0 n − 1 g ( t ) i For t = 0 , all the components of G are initialised with random values (seeds). The refreshment of all components of G from t to t + 1 is based on a chaining process dependent on the refreshment update r ( t + 1 ) : (3) G ( t + 1 ) = ⋃ i = 0 n − 1 g ( t ) i ⊕ r ( t + 1 ) The two previously mentioned sets, E and G, are both made out of symmetric keys randomly initialised (with seeds). Between the two sets, the only difference is the fact that they are different or the same in distinct time intervals (see Eq. (1) and Eq. (3)). The components of these two sets of symmetric keys are together known as the set of distribution keys S: (4) S = E ∪ G The components of the set S may be used indistinctly but always have its origin well identified. By (2.) we associate the routing key ρ(t) to the set G and consequently to S. Note that ρ(t) is a special component of the group keys; although the routing key has a distinct purpose from the group keys (routing authentication and distribution of key updates, respectively), the same key can interchangeably be used for the two purposes. Just as with Eq. The index 0 contains the routing key, which is the same in all VUs, ρ(t). The index d − 1 contains a distinct key in all the subsets, ϵ ν . After the creation of I, each of the auxiliary values on A is loaded into the correspondent VU, and are discarded from the KDC, which only stores I. 4.3.1 Manipulation and synchronisation The KDC performs two types of operations on distribution keys, S: refreshment of group keys G and replacements of the entire S (E and G) and I. The refreshment of G from t to t + 1 is based on a random value, the refreshment update r ( t + 1 ) . All the components of G in the state t are refreshed with r ( t + 1 ) (see Eq. (5)). With the refreshment update r ( t + 1 ) , each of the VUs can perform the same operation in the correspondent subset Pν , (see Eq. (7)), and keep itself synchronised with the KDC. To secretly distribute r(t), the KDC uses one or more distribution keys (either a group key or an exclusive key) from S ( t − 1 ) to encrypt it and produce the correspondent refreshment message. Each refreshment messages sent to the VANET has an encrypted value of r(t), thus each VU with the correct distribution key on the respective subset Pν is able to decrypt it. To refresh the entire VANET from t to t + 1 , the KDC only needs to send one message, with r ( t + 1 ) encrypted with ρ(t). As ρ is known by all VUs, the refreshment update can be used by all of them. Multiple messages, encrypted with different distribution keys, are used to exclude one or more VUs. If one or more VUs were pinpointed as compromised or lost, part of the distribution keys is considered compromised. Among the compromised keys is always ρ, since it is known by all VUs. In this scenario, neither ρ nor any of the distribution keys present in the subsets Pν of the compromised VUs can be used to encrypt r ( t + 1 ) . With the exception of all the distribution keys associated to the compromised VUs, all the others can be safely used as key to encrypt r ( t + 1 ) and produce refreshment messages. Some of those distribution keys are then used to produce the smallest set of refreshment messages, which is enough to update all but the VUs to exclude. In the KDC, once the excluded VUs are marked as compromised, future requests based on the fallback method (see Section 4.2.2) are ignored. The other type of operation performed by the KDC is the replacement of the exclusive keys on E and images on I, used to re-include any of the compromised VUs. To re-include a VU ν that was compromised at the time interval tc , the exclusive key ϵ ν is replaced by a new random value (seed) associated to the most recent time interval, tr . Besides that, a new αν is randomly generated and the image, iν , in the set I is replaced by a new value i ν = H ( α ν ) . After this, the same device, or a different one, can safely take the identification of ν and be loaded with the new value of ϵ ν , associated to tr , along with the αν (αν is then discarded from KDC). The existence of a seed with a time interval tr greater than tc indicates that the VU was resurrected. Since the compromised version of VU was explicitly excluded from the refreshment process, the newly resurrected VU, with the new ϵ associated to tr , inherits the old context and needs to use the fallback method (see Section 4.2.2) to synchronise its subset of distribution keys P. Since the exclusive key ϵ ν was replaced, the KDC can recognise the messages produced by the resurrected instance of ν, encrypted with the new ϵ ν , and provide the needed data. 4.3.2 Recovering from the disclosure of all the distribution keys Upon a successful attack, the KDC may be compromised and all its distribution keys S disclosed (including ρ and all exclusive keys ϵ). After such an event, the distribution keys no longer guarantee the secrecy of any new data distributed with them. By compromising the KDC, an attacker may also have access to the set of images, I, but this is not relevant. To reset all the keys in all the VUs, the KDC sends a reset message, a special refreshment message (without refreshment key), associated to state t + 1 . At the same time, the KDC replaces all the distribution keys S (both E and G) by new ones associated to t + 2 . On state t + 1 all the VUs are excluded from the chained process (none of them can use refreshment messages), but are allowed (informed!) to reset the subset Pν to t + 2 . The reset is performed based on the fallback method (see Section 4.2.2) with an extra step, which will guarantee the secrecy of the new values being distributed. All the VUs will secretly receive their correspondent subset Pν with the new keys, previously created on state t + 2 . The extra step relies on the set of images I and the correspondent set of auxiliary values A. The set I is stored in the KDC, so also compromised, but the auxiliary values are distributed along the VUs. For each VU ν, the KDC can receive each αν , encrypted with its asymmetric public key, compute H(αν ) and compare it with the correspondent iν of I. Assuming the secrecy of the private key of the KDC, a compromised KDC can recover from the disclosure of all the distribution keys stored on it, because it is possible to distinguish a sync request made by a VU and a sync request made by the attacker that holds E but not the distributed A. The reply from the KDC to each VU ν, instead of being encrypted with the disclosed key ϵ ν , is in this case encrypted with αν . The inclusion of αν encrypted with the KDC public key creates an overhead on the fallback method. Although this step is essential to recover from the disclosure of all the distribution keys, it does not need to be present on the requests that will be made by VUs to recover from a period of isolation. Fortunately, the two scenarios are easy to distinguish because the first one is triggered by a reset message. In case of the KDC being compromised along with some of the VUs, the recovering must be done in two steps: first recover from the disclosure of all the distribution keys, and then the exclusion of the compromised VUs. 4.4 Identification of keys and VUs The distribution keys S are arranged in a complete binary tree structure, where the number of leaves, V, is the maximum number of VUs supported by the KDC. Hereafter, we will assume that the number of VUs is equal to V = 2 v , for any v ∈ N + , unless otherwise stated. Each component of S is associated to a node of the binary tree. On the root node, we have the routing key ρ, on each leaf we have a different exclusive key ϵ (all the elements of E are in the leaf level). The binary tree defines successive binary partitions of the VANET. For each partition, it is given a new and distinct key. Fig. 4 illustrates a scenario for a VANET with a maximum of 4 VUs. Since the binary tree is a complete binary tree, with V leaves, allowing up to V VUs in the VANET, the number of elements of S is 2 · V − 1 , and the number of distribution keys stored in each VU is log 2 ( V ) + 1 . Instead of a tree with V leaves, we represent our tree as a main tree where on each of its leaves (main leaves) we have an inner tree with the same size. Moreover, the main tree and the inner tree have the same number of leaves, l: (9) l = V We use the same indexes for both branch nodes and leaves of the trees. By branch nodes, we mean all the nodes that are not leaves. In a complete binary tree with l leaves, there are l − 1 branch nodes. Fig. 5 illustrates such division for V = 16 and l = 4 . The main tree is composed by 3 branch nodes (blue circles) and 4 leaves (green triangles); each of the leaves of the main tree contains an inner tree composed by 3 branch nodes (orange circles) and 4 leaves (red triangles); the 16 VUs are assigned to the 16 leaves of the 4 inner trees. It is possible to distinguish all the branch nodes with indexes from 0 up to l − 2 . Similarly it is possible to distinguish all the leaves with indexes from 0 up to l − 1 . Based on this, for each tree we can use a variable length code for indexing both branch nodes and leaves, with indexes of branch nodes taking half of the size of indexes of leaf nodes. If the first part is between 0 and l − 2 (different from l − 1 ), the index refers to a branch node, and there is not a second part. If the first part is equal to l − 1 (an invalid index for branch nodes), it indicates that there is a second part, with the index of the leaf. To distinguish between branch nodes and leaves of a single tree, we have a code with 1 or 2 parts. Since we have a main tree and multiple inner trees, to distinguish all the nodes (all the components of S), we have a left-to-right variable code with 1 (branch nodes of main tree), 3 (branch nodes of the inner tree) and 4 (leaf nodes of an inner tree) parts. We do not use the leaf nodes of the main tree alone by their own, so there are no codes with 2 parts. For the example presented in Fig. 5, the variable length codes of the distribution keys are shown in Table 1 . Under all the circumstances, the distribution keys associated to the branch nodes of the main tree are the most used, and the less used are the ones associated to leaf nodes of inner trees; thus, we have a shorter identification for the most used indexes. Although the indexes of the distribution keys associated to VUs (the set E) are composed by 4 parts, to distinguish among VUs, only 2 of those parts contain meaningful information: the indexes of both leaves. The routing information is the same of the base protocol. Instead of a beacon solely with the routing information, VUs send a beacon with these elements: • Routing information; • Time interval, t, of the most recent routing key ρ; • Extra payload; • State of the historical cache (see Section 4.2.1); • MAC computed with ρ(t). Assuming the secrecy of ρ(t) across VUs, the routing process is protected against external attackers, due to the MAC. To support updates of ρ(t), beacons can carry an extra payload, either refreshment messages, sync messages or reset messages. Both types of messages are associated to a well-defined time interval, and both carry some auxiliary control information for that specific time interval: the number of distinct refreshment messages produced by KDC, the size of the historical cache and the basal refreshment rate, respectively, h and brr. 4.5.1 Refreshment messages The refreshment messages are built by the KDC, according to Fig. 7 , with the goal of secretly distributing a refreshment update r ( t + 1 ) to all or part of the VUs. The refreshment messages are made by: • r ( t + 1 ) encrypted with an element of S(t); • Identification of the element of S(t) used to encrypt r ( t + 1 ) ; • Value of t; • Control information (number of distinct refreshment messages, brr, h); • KDC signature. To distribute r ( t + 1 ) to the entire VANET it is produced only one refreshment message, with r ( t + 1 ) encrypted with ρ. Since ρ is a common entry in all the subsets P, this key is the best candidate to encrypt r ( t + 1 ) . This is enough to protect the VANET against external attackers, unless such attackers had access to ρ. To exclude one or more VUs, the KDC uses the binary tree structure to select a minimum set of safe distribution keys. All the distribution keys present on the subset of any of the VUs to exclude are considered compromised keys. The minimum set of safe keys is built based on all the siblings, not flagged as unused (see Section 4.4.1), of nodes with compromised keys. If there is more than one VU to exclude, from the previous group of selected siblings are excluded the ones that are compromised. After generating multiple refreshment messages for t + 1 , non-excluded VUs will update from ρ(t) to ρ ( t + 1 ) . For t + 2 the KDC will again produce a single refreshment message, using ρ ( t + 1 ) as the only distribution key. This happens because all of the excluded VUs were unable to receive r ( t + 1 ) and update their state to t + 1 , thus, are unable to decrypt any future refreshment messages, and more important, they are unable to create MACs with the most recent ρ ( t + 1 ) present in VANET. From VUs to the KDC, request messages are made by: • VU identification, ν; • Last time interval, t, known by the VU (the current status of Pν ); • Auxiliary key, αν , encrypted with the public key of the KDC (this is only present after the reception of a reset message, see Section 4.3.2); • MAC of the previous content computed with the last exclusive key, ϵ ν ; • MAC of the previous content computed with the last routing key, ρ(t). and the replies are made out of: • VU identification, ν; • The ordered subset Pν encrypted with ϵ ν or αν (see Section 4.3.2); • Time interval of the encrypted Pν ; • Control information; • KDC signature. 5 Evaluation: results and discussion To evaluate TROPHY we built a trace-based emulator for both OBUs and RSUs that communicate with a KDC, according to a realistic model of a VANET. We also built a prototype of the KDC and prepared it to accommodate up to 216 (65536) VUs. The emulator was fed with 24 hours of traces collected from Veniam’s VANET on Porto city on February 2015, containing 396 OBUs and 50 RSUs. All VUs send periodic beacons in intervals of 100 milliseconds, informing all neighbours about their current state. The data samples have the logged state of all nodes in periods of 2 seconds, including their geographic position and a list of the neighbours listened during the 2 seconds, along with their beacon signal strength. The area used by OBUs is around 21.1 by 18.5 km while the RSUs are mostly placed in the city centre. The area covered by the VANET is shown in Fig. 9 . We implemented the routing protocol used in the VANET (see Section 2) and, based on the lists of the neighbours per VU, we emulated the transmission and reception of routing beacons in periods of 100 milliseconds and enforced their authentication. Furthermore, we emulated the connections made by the RSUs to the KDC and appended to the beacons, on a needed basis, the refreshment messages produced by the KDC as well as the requests for sync messages produced by OBUs and the respective replies produced by KDC. By using real traces with both location and signal strength associated to the received WAVE beacons, we captured the characteristics of the periodic packet-level communications in the VANET. The traces are an outcome that embeds the impact of several transmission issues, such as radio shadowing and MAC (Medium Access Control) collisions; therefore, all mobility, propagation and MAC were taken from real traces, avoiding the use of mathematical models. To evaluate TROPHY in scenarios with worst communication conditions given captured traces, starting from such traces we created a harsh artificial scenario where periodic packet-level communications suffer from severe losses (see Section 5.3.2). While piggybacking TROPHY in the simulated beacons, we are creating differences at the level of the captured MAC layer due to possible channel errors. However, the harsh artificial scenario largely outstrips any possible influence of the piggybacked data in the MAC layer [25,60], and so, the related results represent an extreme lower limit of the performance of TROPHY. 5.1 Input data The collected traces have its origin in a VANET made out of public buses, garbage trucks, and Porto municipality vehicles. Based on the real traces we built two different sets of input for the emulator, one where the VUs communicate with neighbours up to 1 km (the maximum value present in samples) and another one up to 100 metres. For the 100 metres limit nearly 23% less are beacons received. Most of the beacons listened by VUs are received from a neighbour in a near range, as shown in Fig. 10 . The number of active OBUs is variable along the day, with a maximum of 396 and a minimum of 40, as shown in Fig. 11 . While active, the OBUs may be isolated from the VANET. We measured the average time that OBUs are isolated, in minutes per hour. This time is dependent of the data set in use, for communications limited to 1 km it is shown in Fig. 12 . For communications limited to 100 metres, the results followed the same pattern, with the values of isolation time increasing from 0 to 10 minutes. When active, the VUs are exchanging beacons with the neighbours. Since the communications are based on broadcasted messages, without any mechanism to ensure the reception of the messages, the communication created among VUs may not be bidirectional: a VU, ν 1, may be able to listen a neighbour, ν 2, while ν 2 cannot listen ν 1. Since our solution relies on an epidemic propagation of messages according to the needs of the neighbours, the bidirectional communications are important and the presence of unidirectional communications may have a negative impact. The percentage of bidirectional connections created by OBUs and RSUs as well as the discriminated unidirectional connections for RSUs (can listen but cannot be listened or the opposite) are shown in Fig. 13 . It is important to notice that the OBUs can exchange beacons with RSUs and other OBUs while the RSUs only exchange beacons with OBUs. The percentage of unidirectional communications found in the OBUs is between 5% and 10%. In the case of RSUs there is some variation, between 0 and 30%. The time since the last direct connection with an RSU made by the OBUs is shown in Fig. 14 . The analysis of Fig. 11, Fig. 12 and Fig. 13 suggests that approximately from 23: 00 to 6: 00 the VANET may be susceptible to communication problems. The problems may be caused by three different reasons that individually occur for a relatively small period, but all in continuous time window, namely: • A small number of active OBUs, especially from 4: 00 to 5: 00 (see Fig. 11); • A high number of OBUs isolated for a large period, around 5: 00. More than 75% of the active OBUs are isolated more than 30 (non-continuous) minutes during 1 h (see Fig. 12); • A high percentage of unidirectional communicating between RSUs and OBUs, from 1: 00 to 2: 30 and around 23: 00 and 6: 00 (see Fig. 13). 5.2 TROPHY messages: size, number and occurrence To accommodate up to 216 VUs, we have the same number of inner leaves in the KDC, with both main and inner trees having l = 256 leaves (see Eq. (9)). Consequently, in this case, the identification of each VU takes 2 bytes. For the symmetric cipher, we chose the AES128, so the symmetric keys have 16 bytes. We assume the use of HMAC-MD5 as the MAC function, with an output of 16 bytes, and the use of ECDSA, as the asymmetric signature algorithm, more precisely ECDSA-224 with a signature of 56 bytes and a public key with 28 bytes. These technologies were chosen based on the security currently provided,  ≥  112 bits of security strength [28], and the current recommendations for the near future [61], up to 2030. With the best expectations being to use the protocol without any update up to 2030, we use 3 bytes to define the time intervals (the number of minutes up to 2030 is less than 224). Comparing with SB2RP, with the proposed configuration, the routing beacons have extra 20 bytes (16 bytes for the MACs, 3 bytes for the time interval and 1 byte to advertise the state of the historical cache), plus the size of the optional refreshment or sync messages. The 20 bytes increment is independent of the maximum number of VUs supported by TROPHY and only dependent of the algorithm used to produce the MAC and the expected period of continuous work. The refreshment messages have between 80 to 83 bytes and this size is mostly independent of the maximum number of VUs supported. In the refreshment messages the only parameter dependent of (the logarithm of) the maximum number of VUs is the number of distinct refreshment messages present in the control information (see Section 4.5.1). The requests for sync messages sent by the OBUs have 37 or 293 bytes while the replies of sync messages sent by the KDC have 340 bytes. The sync messages are the most dependent from the maximum number of VUs, since in both it is sent the identification of the VUs. Moreover, the replies from KDC have log (V) encrypted keys (with 16 bytes in our case). In Eq. For those scenarios, we looked for the lower bounds of use and the respective parameters. This goal led to some stressful configurations that are not expected to find equivalent in a real context, but still, are useful for the evaluation. On each scenario, we tested different parameters and in some cases, based on the results, we fixed and carried on with the best parameters to some other test scenarios. The tested scenarios were divided into 5 different groups: fixed periods of refreshment, adverse communication conditions, successive exclusions of a single VU, single exclusion of multiple VUs and reset of all the KDC keys. For each scenario, we evaluated 8 distinct time-dependent parameters, namely: a) Percentage of beacons received with a valid MAC; b) Percentage of routes lost due to security (assuming routes between OBUs and RSUs with a maximum of 3 hops, according to SB2RP); c) Percentage of equivalent routes (same route to same destination, with or without security); d) Percentage of secure routes with more hops; e) Percentage of secure routes with the same number of hops but using a path with lower quality (based on Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI)); f) Total number of refreshment messages cached in the active VUs; g) Percentage of beacons transmitted with the overhead of a refreshment message; h) Percentage of beacons transmitted with the overhead of a sync message. The x-axis of the graphics presented, contain the time of the day associated to the real data samples. We also analysed two geographical-dependent parameters: the percentage of updated OBUs per location and the percentage of beacons received with a valid MAC per location. We present the results over a simplified map of the Porto city in white and Atlantic Ocean, Douro River and Leixões harbour in blue. 5.3.1 Fixed periods of refreshment We tested different periods to distribute a single refreshment message with the unique aim of updating the routing key, ρ. With communications up to 1 km, we tested periods of 10 minutes, 1 h and 2 hours. All the tests were initially done allowing the OBUs to cache the refreshment messages to the last 8 time intervals. Based on the results with the period of 10 minutes, we inspected the impact of the variation on the historical cache, setting it to 32. The results of the several performance metrics for the 4 configurations are shown in Fig. 16 . Globally, we observe that the overhead of the messages associated to the secure routing is only present in a small percentage of the transmitted beacons (2.5% maximum in Fig. 16 g and 0.27% in Fig. 16 h). Moreover, there is a ratio of approximately 1 10 for those two types of transmitted messages, with the bigger ones (sync messages) being the less frequent. Since TROPHY messages are piggybacked on top of SB2RP, those results are according to one of the main goals of TROPHY: messages needed to keep the security process should only be present in a small number of SB2RP messages, and the majority of those messages should be the small refreshment messages rather than the big sync messages. Regarding the percentage of valid beacons, the period of 2 hours has the best results, with values close to 100%. Consequently, the routes created, based on the received beacons, have minor changes: the percentage of routes lost is residual, always lower than 0.25% (Fig. 16 b); most of the routes are the same, always greater than 97.5% (Fig. 16 c); the routes that are not equivalent are replaced by alternatives with more hops or lower quality. The percentage of valid beacons associated to the other periods of refreshments (10 minutes and 1 h) is highly affected by the limit imposed on the historical cache. For the period of 1 h caching, the last 8 messages correspond to 8 hours, while for the period of 10 minutes it corresponds to 1: 20 (8 time intervals) and 5: 20 (32 time intervals). After filling the cache, all these cases have associated a variation on the percentage of valid beacons, meaning that VUs do not keep the refreshment messages needed to update the neighbours. For the 2 hours period, after the filling of the historical (16 hours) there is no observable variation. The number of refreshment messages cached in the VANET (Fig. 16 f) is mostly independent of the period of refreshment, and tend to be dependent on the value used in the historical cache, 8 or 32. As expected, the strong dependency is associated to the number of active VUs (see Fig. 11), clearly visible on the minimum around 5: 00 when less OBUs are active. The higher percentage of lost routes in all the tests are coincident with the time window where it was expectable to have communication problems (see Section 5.1), so from 1: 00 to 6: 00 the VANET is clearly more susceptible to the chosen parameters. A period of 10 minutes combined with a limit of 8 time intervals for the historical cache yields the worst results. With a period of 10 minutes, the higher percentage of valid beacons obtained with a limit of 32 time intervals in the historical cache, is coincident with a higher percentage of overhead caused by refreshment messages and a lower percentage of overhead related with the transmission of sync messages. This is coincident with the activation of a high number of OBUs, at 5: 10 (see Fig. 11) with bidirectional connections with RSUs (see Fig. 14). Although OBUs have contact with RSUs, the epidemic propagation of cached messages reduces the number of sync messages (Fig. 16 g and h respectively). The best and the worst case, respectively 2 hours and 10 minutes periods with the historical cache of 8, are compared in terms of the impact in the different locations. Fig. 17 shows the percentage of updated OBUs per location refreshing the routing key in periods of 10 minutes, and Fig. 18 shows the same information when refreshing the routing key in periods of 2 hours. In the very centre of the city, where most of the RSUs are placed, the impact is imperceptible. In all the remaining area, a shorter refreshment period has a negative impact, meaning that the refreshment messages produced by KDC are not available among the VUs when needed. In the case of periods of two hours, not all the OBUs are immediately updated when moving in the periphery of the city, but still most of the beacons received can be validated (see Fig. 19 ). The absence of a negative impact caused by the outdated VUs moving in the periphery happens due to the partitions in the VANET. Although globally outdated, the VUs can validate beacons among each other and can be updated on a needed basis (when close to updated neighbours). 5.3.2 Adverse communication conditions We tested the behaviour of our solution under adverse communication conditions, limiting the propagation of the refreshment and the sync messages in space and time. The limitation in space is done limiting the communications up to 100 metres, instead of 1 km, with about 23% less received beacons. The limitation in time is done by explicitly discarding 90% of the received beacons in all the VUs. Both conditions are considered artificial and very unlikely to be found in real environments, at least continuously for a wide area during a long period, as we are testing. Nevertheless, the behaviour is indicative for less aggressive and unexpected conditions. With a fixed refreshment of 2 hours, the maximum percentage of invalid beacons was 1.5% and the maximum percentage of lost routes was 1.4%. The overhead of both types of messages was always smaller than 0.1%. Taking these results in consideration, the following scenarios presented will include the case where communications are limited to 100 metres and, at the same time, 90% of the received beacons are discarded in all the VUs.
